nytimes_articles.headline: Safety Changes Discussed for Prospect Park
nytimes_articles.abstract: Brooklyn officials met with community leaders yesterday to discuss how to improve safety in Prospect Park, two days after a 42-year-old drama teacher was shot to death in an apparent robbery there.   Hoping to convince residents of the borough that the park is safe, the officials said increased police patrols should prevent incidents like the slaying of Allyn Winslow, who, the police said, was killed for his mountain bike.

nytimes_articles.headline: Need a Player? Got Young Talent? Call Trader Al
nytimes_articles.abstract: Trades, from the minor to the major to the no-brainer, have not been Al Harazin's strength as general manager of the Mets. He remains on trial for his trading of David Cone last August. And even the deals that the public embraced -- Bret Saberhagen's acquisition and the addition of shortstop Tony Fernandez -- have been undermined by injury and circumstance and maybe a lack of research and constructive suspicion.   Well, Harazin is on the telephone again, and the Shea Stadium faithful might as well take the opportunity to get on the edge of their seats.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; Nightmare The Knicks Won't Forget
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT could be a psychologist's lifework, this collective nightmare. All 12 Knickerbockers and half the population of New York will share the same bad dream, the old slipping-on-ice dream, the old falling-through-air dream, the old cannot-make-a-layup dream.   In this dream, they are all Charles Smith, all 6 feet 10 inches of him, with those long arms, battling bravely under the basket, trying to make a layup against many grasping hands. Time is running out.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kurds and Christians Live in Harmony
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   In "Christian Sects in Kurdish Lands Dwindle" (letter, May 24), Alastair Bruton claims that the numbers of Christians living in the Kurdish area in the north of Iraq and southeast of Turkey have been reduced from 25,000 to 200 or 300 "because the Kurds told them they had no future in a land the Kurds would soon control." Mr. Bruton concludes by appealing for the linkage of "safeguards" to Western aid earmarked for the peoples of Kurdistan-Iraq because otherwise the West will be facilitating "ethnic cleansing" there.   Throughout this century, Muslim Kurds and Christian Assyrians and Chaldeans in Kurdistan-Iraq have enjoyed good and cooperative relations. In the 1930's, for example, the Kurds did not retaliate against Christians who displaced them, in collaboration with British colonialists, from the oil-rich area of Kirkuk. More recently, some Christians have joined Kurdish political parties.   In the 1980's, many Christians left the Kurdish area for Baghdad or destinations abroad for economic reasons. Iraqi Kurds, themselves victims of chemical warfare and an operation that, it is estimated, claimed the lives of 180,000 Kurds, were hardly in a position to force any other people out of the region.    Some Christians fled to Turkey in the April 1991 refugee exodus and refused to return for economic reasons or because they had no homes to which to return. This is documented in reports released by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and in an April 1992 investigation report by the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights.   In the last year, in preparation for the May 1992 election, the Kurdistan Front set aside 5 seats (out of 105) for Christians in the new Kurdish Parliament. This quota assured the representation of Chaldeans and other Christian groups. Because the two major parties hold 50 seats each, the Christian members of the Kurdish Parliament will cast the deciding votes should a stalemate arise.   As the Iraqi military again looms as an ominous presence on the horizon of Kurdistan-Iraq, the fledgling democracy deserves and needs Western humanitarian aid as long as its leaders apply the law equitably to all people. SALAH AZIZ  President, Badlisy Center for Kurdish Studies Tallahassee, Fla., May 25, 1993

nytimes_articles.headline: Impasse Over Damages in New Yorker Libel Case
nytimes_articles.abstract: The celebrated libel trial pitting Jeffrey M. Masson against Janet Malcolm ended inconclusively today when a Federal jury deadlocked on monetary damages after deciding that the writer had defamed him with five fabricated quotations in her article about him in The New Yorker.    A new trial is now likely in the tortuous, decadelong case between a prim East Coast writer and a flamboyant West Coast analyst. But it remains to be decided by Judge Eugene F. Lynch of the United States District Court here whether the entire case will be heard again or merely the damage portion, and whether The New Yorker will remain a defendant.

nytimes_articles.headline: Exiled Haitian Leader Addresses L.I.U.-Brooklyn
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the exiled President of Haiti, delivered the main address via videotape at the Brooklyn campus of Long Island University for its 63d commencement, which was held yesterday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.   Father Aristide, who was deposed in a September 1991 coup, spoke to the 1,000 graduates about the movement to restore democracy in Haiti.

nytimes_articles.abstract: Sea Cliffs  Aquarium for Wildlife Conservation West Eighth Street  and Surf Avenue Coney Island, Brooklyn (718) 265-3474 Recommended for all ages    Out in Coney Island, where the fish still hang out in schools and the Cyclone roller coaster has been carrying riders since 1927, there is a new marine mammal habitat, Sea Cliffs, at what used to be called the New York Aquarium.

nytimes_articles.headline: Park Ave. Car Ban May Clean Air, but Not Words
nytimes_articles.abstract: New York City officials closed a busy section of Park Avenue to traffic for two hours yesterday, and this is what happened:   Electric-powered cars were displayed, volunteers with pedicabs offered free rides and assorted politicians showed up to voice support for anything that would cut pollution and to urge car owners to change their wicked ways.

nytimes_articles.headline: Three's Company: Guinier, Reagan, Bush
nytimes_articles.abstract: The shrill attacks on Lani Guinier, President Clinton's nominee to head the Justice Department's civil rights division, give to those who know her a sense of Kafkaesque unreality.   Her experience, character, respect for the law and balanced approach to the issues would make her one of the finest assistant attorneys general ever to serve our country. She is superbly qualified, mainstream and pro-integrationist in the tradition of Thurgood Marshall. It is essential, if democratic principles are to be preserved, that President Clinton give her the opportunity to defend her record before the Senate Judiciary Committee. For him to yank the nomination now would not only be unfair but, some would say, political cowardice.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jerusalem Journal; Strike! Strike! Strike! Some Arabs Feel Cudgeled
nytimes_articles.abstract: Commercial strikes? In the Muslim Quarter of the Old City, a shoe-store owner repeated key words of the question put to him, then raised a hand to forehead level to make his point about having had it up to there.   "I'm tired of the whole thing -- the strikes and the intifada," he said, using the Arabic word for the Palestinian uprising against Israel.

nytimes_articles.headline: SOUTH AFRICA FOES SET DATE FOR VOTE OPEN TO ALL RACES
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Government and most of South Africa's opposition parties settled tonight on a date -- April 27, 1994 -- for elections in which the country's black majority will cast their first votes.    The tentative agreement, coming after a year and a half of fitful negotiations, would set a timetable for ending more than three centuries of white rule.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sonics Breeze To Force Game 7
nytimes_articles.abstract: Charles Barkley shot his mouth, but not the basketball tonight. He groused at referees, aimed his index finger at them as if it were a gun, slammed a ball halfway to the rafters, incited fans and made no redeeming contribution to the Phoenix Suns. Maybe he was saving his aching body for a deciding seventh game in this Western Conference final, which is exactly what he has on his hands.   Seattle was the more stolid team tonight, and the Sonics delivered an emphatic 118-102 victory before 14,812 at the Seattle Center Coliseum. The series, tame for the first five games, finally has some passion and it will be settled Saturday afternoon in Phoenix.

nytimes_articles.headline: Next Title Defense for Bowe?
nytimes_articles.abstract: ROCK NEWMAN, manager of heavyweight champion RIDDICK BOWE, asked the International Boxing Federation to make Bowe's first mandatory defense against either MICHAEL MOORER or OLIVER McCALL. Moorer is listed second in the latest I.B.F. rankings and McCall is rated third. But first, Newman said, he expected Bowe and former champion EVANDER HOLYFIELD to agree to a rematch in the near future.(AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Love Swings Straight Back Into 1992
nytimes_articles.abstract: A few short months ago it seemed the surest thing in golf was that 1993 would belong to Davis Love 3d.   He was coming off a PGA Tour season in which he won three official tournaments and more than $1 million, and he had added three more unofficial victories in the last two months of the year. To top it off, Love won this year's opening event, the Tournament of Champions.

nytimes_articles.headline: Coach Names Squad for U.S. Cup '93
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bora Milutinovic, head coach of the United States national soccer team, named eight European-based players yesterday to his 22-man roster for the United States Cup '93 tournament, which begins Sunday in New Haven.   Four of the eight players -- Thomas Dooley, Tab Ramos, Frank Klopas and Eric Wynalda -- will miss the opener at the Yale Bowl against Brazil because of previous commitments. They will join the team in time for matches against Germany and England.

nytimes_articles.headline: Guatemala Army Names Vice President as Leader
nytimes_articles.abstract: Amid signs that the military has again taken control of Guatemala's chaotic political situation, the Government announced today that the Vice President, who was supposed to have resigned when President Jorge Serrano Elias was overthrown, was taking over as the country's new leader.   The Vice President, Gustavo Espina Salguero, had still not been sworn in as President tonight, and it is not clear that he has the necessary political support to be ratified by Congress.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: BETTY FRIEDAN has been hospitalized at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center since Tuesday, suffering from an infection that causes severe back pain.   Ms. Friedan underwent surgery twice last month at the Hospital of the Good Samaritan in Los Angeles, to replace an aorta valve. One replacement came from a pig, the second from a human.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.N. Told of Cease-Fire in Muslim Town
nytimes_articles.abstract: The commander of the United Nations military forces in Bosnia said today that the leader of the Bosnian Serbs had told him that he had ordered a cease-fire around the besieged Muslim town of Gorazde.   Lieut. Gen. Philippe Morillon has been pressing Bosnian Serbs for days to allow military observers into Gorazde, which has been designated a safe area by the United Nations. "I have insisted that these observers must be deployed no later than tomorrow to show good faith," the general said after his meeting with Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader.

nytimes_articles.headline: Thousands of Germans Rally for the Slain Turks
nytimes_articles.abstract: Thousands of residents of this once-placid town, now known around the world as the site of a terror attack that killed five Turkish women and girls, gathered today to lament the attack and bid farewell to their slain neighbors.   "We are horrified," Solingen's Mayor, Gerd Kraimer, told the crowd. "We are deeply ashamed. We ask for forgiveness."

nytimes_articles.headline: Spanish Students Rebelling Against the Left
nytimes_articles.abstract: One day in the mid-1960's, when Manuel Fraga Iribarne went to speak at the University of Seville, a long-haired undergraduate named Felipe Gonzalez was in the crowd of young leftists who cheerfully yelled and booed Franco's Minister of Information.   The irony was not lost on Mr. Gonzalez when he visited the Autonomous University of Madrid on March 25. Now in his 11th year as Spain's Socialist Prime Minister, it was his turn to be heckled -- this time by student sympathizers of the conservative People's Party founded by Mr. Fraga himself.

nytimes_articles.headline: Edberg Derailed by Medvedev
nytimes_articles.abstract: Stefan Edberg referred to himself as being on the right track here at the French Open, where all he needed was the title in order to become the first man to collect all four Grand Slam crowns since Rod Laver mastered that elusive quad in 1969.   But in Andrei Medvedev, an upstart teen-ager from Ukraine, Edberg today ran smack into a runaway train in their rain-delayed quarterfinal on the stadium court. In the best tradition of the local fountainry, Edberg's hairline was spouting rivulets of water from the effort of trying to counteract the grim power of Medvedev. And the youngster's seemingly automated service returns pressured the Swede to be perfect. Which he wasn't.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gay Film Festival: The Personal and the Political
nytimes_articles.abstract: In "I'll Love You Forever . . . Tonight," Edgar Michael Bravo's gritty portrait of gay life in Los Angeles, a sullen young photographer is coaxed by his sometime lover into spending the weekend with some friends at a Palm Springs hideaway. What is supposed to be a restful little vacation turns into a joyless round of hard drinking and cold-blooded sexual games played by five good-looking men who seem totally at loose ends. Their emotional cruelty reminds the photographer of his childhood abuse by his father, whom he eventually telephones for an excruciating confrontation.    The tone of Mr. Bravo's film, which is being shown today and tomorrow at the Cinema Village as part of the New Festival, also called the 1993 New York Lesbian and Gay Film Festival, suggests Mart Crowley's play "The Boys in the Band," as it might be adapted and updated for 1993 in the spirit of Bret Easton Ellis's novel "Less Than Zero." If the film offers a bleak picture of one segment of gay life, it carries a nasty ring of truth.

nytimes_articles.headline: Good Life in Gabon Comes at a Heavy Price
nytimes_articles.abstract: Against a backdrop of opulent residences and elegant restaurants, Boulevard Georges Pompidou, a scenic roadway overlooking the Atlantic coast here, could easily be mistaken for a glittering stretch along the French Riviera.    It is all part of the good life that this tiny Central African country of sandy beaches, isolated coves and ruggedly beautiful mountains can offer. It is a splendor, however, that costs dearly.

nytimes_articles.headline: Majority in Poll Back Ban on Handguns
nytimes_articles.abstract: Americans watching the increase in gunshot injuries and deaths among the country's children are beginning to see gun control as a question of public health rather than just a matter of crime prevention, according to a new survey made public today.   The survey, by Louis Harris of LH Research Inc., showed that one adult in five knows a child who had been shot by another child, and another 12 percent know a child who shot himself by accident. The study, done under a grant from the Chicago-based Joyce Foundation for the Harvard School of Public Health, found that three-quarters of adults surveyed believed "young people's safety is endangered by there being so many guns around these days."  9 Out of 10 Back Bill    As a result, the new poll found, public opinion is rapidly swinging in favor of more stringent gun control measures.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Film; Games Meticulous And Mean
nytimes_articles.abstract: "The Music of Chance" was shown as part of the recent New Directors/ New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 19, 1993. The film opens today at the Fine Arts, 4 West 58th Street, Manhattan.    A miniature city is the haunting centerpiece of "The Music of Chance," Philip Haas's cool, methodical film version of Paul Auster's equally meticulous 1990 novel. Called City of the World, it is the bizarre play thing of Willie Stone (Joel Grey), a former optometrist who made his fortune by winning the lottery. Together with his friend Bill Flower (Charles Durning), Stone lives in an isolated mansion and contemplates the meaning of fate while playing childlike games. The City of the World is his masterwork. James Nashe (Mandy Patinkin) and Jack Pozzi (James Spader) are his victims.

nytimes_articles.headline: Critic's Notebook; Garbo's Grittier 'Anna Christie'
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHEN Garbo talked in the 1930 Hollywood version of "Anna Christie," she had to speak not only English but also the language of Eugene O'Neill. Fighting her way through the "Py gollys" and "Now, me old buckos" of the 1922 play (which gives Anna a Swedish father and an Irish suitor), Garbo struggled visibly to match the expansiveness of the material. She gave a stirring but stagy performance under the direction of Clarence Brown, who had guided her through the 1927 "Flesh and the Devil," would later direct her in "Anna Karenina" (1935) and clearly understood the Garbo mystique. At the same time, in another language, Garbo did something unusual with "Anna Christie": she made it again.   "Her contralto voice seems better suited to talking German than English," wrote the New York Times critic Mordaunt Hall when the German "Anna Christie," directed by Jacques Feyder on the same sets that Mr. Brown had used, opened here briefly in 1931. "Her presence is if anything more striking in this current work than in the English version."

nytimes_articles.headline: Babbitt a Candidate for High Court
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton said today that "we're close" to announcing a choice for a Supreme Court seat, and White House officials said the short list for that nomination now included Bruce Babbitt, the Interior Secretary.   Presidential aides said that although Mr. Clinton might yet select a sitting judge to replace Justice Byron R. White, who will retire this month, he wanted a candidate with whom he is close and comfortable, as he is with Mr. Babbitt.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tyson and Cayton Settle
nytimes_articles.abstract: After four years, MIKE TYSON and his former boxing manager, BILL CAYTON, decided to settle their legal suits against each other, according to court papers reviewed Wednesday in United States District Court in Manhattan.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pay Too High?
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "At What Point Is Pay Too High?" asks the headline over your article on the compensation of Leonard Tow, chief executive officer of Citizens Utilities (Business Day, May 21).    I suggest an appropriate answer to that question is one my manager at a major corporation gave me years ago. "Your salary," he told me, "is designed to keep you sullen but not mutinous. If you're satisfied, it's too high. If you quit, it's too low. The right amount is somewhere between these two limits." SHERMAN SIEGEL  King of Prussia, Pa., May 21, 1993

nytimes_articles.headline: Animal Laboratory Evacuated After Power Loss
nytimes_articles.abstract: Scientists were evacuated from a building at the Plum Island Animal Disease Center on Wednesday morning after a brief power failure triggered a release of toxic formaldehyde gas.   Today, officials of the Long Island Lighting Company said that the power failure was caused by an osprey nest atop a transmission line pole.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sotheby's Challenged In Selling Declaration
nytimes_articles.abstract: It is a first printing of the Declaration of Independence -- a clear, crisp copy that sold for $2.4 million two years ago -- and yesterday it became enmeshed in a Manhattan court fight over ownership and resale rights.   A fine arts investment firm, Visual Equities Inc., of Atlanta, obtained a court order temporarily blocking Sotheby's from selling the Declaration after charging that the Manhattan auction house had misled the firm and tried to defraud it at an unsuccessful auction last month.

nytimes_articles.headline: On My Min; Our Friend Qaddafi
nytimes_articles.abstract: For a while, many Americans asked themselves a sensible and healthy question every time they walked aboard a passenger plane -- is this another Pan Am 103?   The question was sensible because terrorists can do again what they did on Dec. 21, 1988 -- bring down a planeload of 259 people. And it was healthy, because as long as Americans asked it, there was a chance that terrorism could be stopped permanently.

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Kerri Scharlin, Darren M. Brown  Dooley Le Cappellaine 252 Lafayette Street SoHo Through tomorrow    These two solo shows stress the continuing interest in context, in the world around and beyond the art object. The work in Kerri Scharlin's show has been made by art students, who drew and sculptured from a nude model who was the artist herself. Their treatments of her face and body attest to different degrees of talent and style. (The small clay sculptures are sometimes rather good.) But the main point here seems to be that it is the female model who occupies center stage. A new kind of one-woman show.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dinkins Plans More Cuts To Fill $280 Million Gap
nytimes_articles.abstract: All but giving up hope that New York City would receive much of the state and Federal aid they had been seeking, senior aides to Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday presented their most dire view yet of the city's fiscal condition.   They said they would now be forced to cut city spending by $280 million in the next fiscal year, including scaling back by half the 8,000 workers they had planned to hire. The spending plan that Mr. Dinkins presented last month called for a net increase of 1,500 workers during the next year; officials now expect to shrink the work force.

nytimes_articles.headline: Diner's Journal
nytimes_articles.abstract: Daniel in the Mainstream    Is the new Manhattan restaurant Daniel merely Le Cirque without Sirio? Well, no and yes. When Daniel Boulud left his mentor, Sirio Maccioni, owner of Le Cirque, last year to open his own place, fans of his astonishingly diversified French cooking wondered where his talents would lead next. Would he paddle down some exotic tributary the way Jean-Georges Vongerichten of Jo-Jo did when he opened Vong? Would he embrace some neglected regional French cuisine?   As a recent visit to Daniel reveals, Mr. Boulud did no such thing. Daniel, on East 76th Street near Fifth Avenue, offers the kind of technically impeccable, labor-intensive French cooking that made Mr. Boulud a star at Le Cirque. People looking for innovation may be disappointed; those looking for world-class French fare will not be.

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; Echoes of the Vietnam War Are Still Resounding
nytimes_articles.abstract: The late, great Vietnam War lasted more than 10 years -- longer than the United States engagement in two World Wars and the Korean War -- and it continues to be a guiding fact in American foreign and military policy. The Vietnam Syndrome remains a cautionary warning against adventurism in no-win wars or, contrariwise, as a lingering attitude that some unrepentant hawks want discarded. The famous hundred-hour victory in the Persian Gulf was sui generis; it hasn't changed the views of key American decision makers, who do not want to stumble into the current ethnic-religious-border war in the Balkans.   Nearly two decades after the end of the Vietnam War, a new round of books explores the war's aims; how and why the United States got involved; who the Vietnamese people are and what they thought about the foreigners who came to their villages as warriors; the behavior of American soldiers in battle; the campus wars and the peace movement at home, and how correspondents reported the war while facing pressure from their publications, networks and government.

nytimes_articles.headline: Questions Rise Over Fate Of Simon's Art Museum
nytimes_articles.abstract: The death of Norton Simon prompted questions and speculation yesterday about the fate of a national treasure, the Norton Simon Museum of Art in Pasadena, Calif., which houses many precious works of art that he collected over the decades.   In the past there was talk that the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., would eventually pay the Simon Museum's operating costs and that its works would be acquired by the Getty collection. But Janet Ellis, the executive administrator to the Norton Museum's director, Walter W. Timoshuk, said yesterday, "We are going to continue to function as we have in the past."

nytimes_articles.headline: Leyritz Puts His Bat Where His Bravado Is
nytimes_articles.abstract: The day he made the major leagues, Jim Leyritz called his father. Don Leyritz did not say congratulations. He did not say, "I'm proud of you." He told his son, succinctly, "to go out there and do something." He expected him to make an immediate impact, he expected him to produce.   Jim expected the same thing. He arrived in the Yankee clubhouse with huge minor league numbers and an ego to match. He was brash, and admittedly arrogant, and he drove his teammates wild with his constant posturing. "Give me an opportunity," he said to anyone who would listen, "and I'll show you what I can do."

nytimes_articles.headline: RESULTS PLUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: TRACK AND FIELD  L.S.U. Women Near 7th Straight Title  Danyel Mitchell won the women's discus throw yesterday as Louisiana State's women's team rolled toward its seventh consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association championship at Tad Gormley Stadium in New Orleans. Mitchell's winning throw was 186 feet 6 inches, 40 inches better than the 183-2 of runner-up Dawn Dumble of U.C.L.A. Third was Stacy Schroeder, a University of Florida freshman from Grand Island, N.Y. Schroeder, last year's New York state high school champion in the shot-put and discus, registered the best performance of her career with a throw of 180-1. Kelly Blair of Oregon, with 6,038 points, won the heptathlon. Fourth in the seven-event competition was Shana Williams of Seton Hall (5,640). Randy Jenkins of Tennessee won the men's high jump. Jenkins, who finished second in in 1991 but missed last year's meet because of Hodgkins' disease, won with a jump of 7 feet 5 3/4 inches.  Powell Long Jumps 27-10 3/4 for Victory  Mike Powell of the United States, the world-record holder at 29 feet 4 1/2 inches, got off his best long jump of the early outdoor season, leaping 27-10 3/4 to win the event at the Madrid International in Spain. Ivan Pedroso of Cuba, the 1993 world indoor champion, was second at 27-7 1/4. In the day's major upset, China's Li Tong defeated the Olympic silver medalist Tony Dees of the United States in the 110-meter hurdles in 13.62 seconds. Dees ran 13.70. Renaldo Nehemiah, the former world-record holder from the United States, was fifth in 13.82. (AP) COLLEGE BASEBALL  Cal Poly Eliminates Adelphi From Tourney  Grant Munger hit a pair of home runs to lead Cal Poly to an 11-5 victory over Adelphi in Montgomery, Ala., yesterday that propelled the Mustangs (39-18) into tomorrow night's championship game and eliminated the Panthers (32-17) from the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II tournament. Dom Gatti, the Division II player of the year, led the losers from Garden City, L.I., with three singles. (AP) ROWING  Brown and Penn Win Heats in Eights  Eighty-five crews from 23 colleges competed on the opening day of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's 91st regatta, at the Cooper River in Cherry Hill, N.J. The Brown varsity eight, which last month won the first part of rowing's triple crown, the Eastern Sprints, breezed through its qualifying heat yesterday, winning in 5 minutes 37.6 seconds. The other varsity heat winner, as expected, was Penn in 5:38.4. The 10 non-winners will row today in two repechage races, with first and second-place finishers qualifying for tomorrow's six-boat finale. Brown and Northeastern crews won the second varsity heats while freshman eights from Brown, Navy and Princeton placed first in their three heats.

nytimes_articles.headline: DO'S AND DON'TS
nytimes_articles.abstract: On Your Feet

nytimes_articles.headline: The Pentagon Sheds a Myth
nytimes_articles.abstract: For more than 40 years the armed forces bolstered their drive for new weaponry and bigger budgets with the argument that America must be prepared to fight two wars in distant parts of the world at once. But in fact they've never had the capability to do that, and the Pentagon, in a long overdue and healthy concession to reality, is ready to end the masquerade.    Instead of planning to wage simultaneous wars in two different theaters, it is considering a new strategy of "win-hold-win" -- in effect, fighting wars one at a time. Under the new doctrine, the Pentagon would fight one war on the ground, while it tries to hold off another aggressor with air power and forces from allied countries until it can commit its own ground troops.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gaetti Is Released by Angels
nytimes_articles.abstract: GARY GAETTI, a free-agent third baseman who failed to live up to his All-Star credentials after signing an $11.4 million, four-year contract with California, was placed on release waivers yesterday by the Angels.   The move made room for KELLY GRUBER, who will join the team today after completing a rehabilitation assignment at the Angels' farm team in Vancouver, British Columbia. The 31-year-old Gruber, acquired from Toronto in a trade last winter, has been on the disabled list since spring training after he underwent rotator cuff and shoulder surgery in February.

nytimes_articles.headline: Two Bucks Will Finance Health Care for 10 Million
nytimes_articles.abstract:
The fate of the Clinton Administration's again-delayed program to reform the country's health care system will hinge on sources of revenue. Cigarettes, which are detrimental to the health of Americans, are likely to enhance the health of the program.

A $2 per pack increase in the Federal excise tax on cigarettes, which is now 24 cents a pack, is under consideration. But Government economists cannot easily predict its impact. An extra $2 would bring the current average retail price to $4 a pack. Would smoking rates drop so steeply that cigarette revenues would fall?

nytimes_articles.headline: Sihanouk Names a Government In Cambodia, Then Withdraws
nytimes_articles.abstract: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's former monarch, announced Thursday that he had formed a coalition government in which he would serve as Prime Minister and supreme military commander, only to abandon the plan this morning in the midst of what is apparently a long-running family psychodrama pitting Prince Sihanouk against one of his sons.   The son, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, had originally been named Deputy Prime Minister in the new newly proclaimed National Government of Cambodia.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Art; 20th-Century Latin American Works at the Modern
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Latin American Artists of the 20th Century," the sprawling survey at the Museum of Modern Art, is something of a feast, and something of a fiasco. The largest exhibition of 20th-century Latin American art ever assembled, it occupies 25 galleries and much of the ground-floor lobby at the museum, achieving a state of almost mind-boggling complexity. Although clearly intended as a sweeping overview, it is more a sweeping glimpse, partial, fragmented and confused.    The exhibition sets before the visitor nearly 300 works, created by more than 90 artists during the last 80 years. It begins with the Cubist canvases of the great Mexican artist Diego Rivera and ends with paintings and installation works by contemporary artists like Guillermo Kuitca, Julio Galan, Eugenio Dittborn and Alfredo Jaar, all of whom are increasingly and for the most part deservedly prominent on the international art circuit. In between, the exhibition seeks to demonstrate how the modernist ideas issuing from Paris, Moscow and Berlin in the early decades of this century ignited an amazing chain of indigenous reactions and permutations throughout Central and South America, as they did in other parts of Europe and in the United States.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. and Europeans Planning U.N. Vote on Bosnia Havens
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United States and its European allies decided tonight to call a Security Countil vote on Friday on their plan to send troops to guard six Muslim enclaves in Bosnia and Herzegovina that have been designated as safe havens.   But nearly two weeks after Secretary of State Warren Christopher and the Foreign Ministers of Britain, France, Spain and Russia first approved the plan in Washington, members from developing countries are trying to block action on putting put it into effect. It was unclear tonight whether they would support the plan, abstain or adopt divergent positions if the vote is taken by the Council's 15 members.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Art Market
nytimes_articles.abstract: Tale of 2 Cities   Many of the late 19th- and early-20th-century masterpieces by such artists as Matisse, Cezanne, van Gogh, Redon and Picasso that are in the Cone Collection, the jewel in the Baltimore Museum of Art's crown since 1949, are traveling to the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston. Perfect timing made the loan possible.   Originally, the collection was to be dismantled and placed in storage while the Baltimore Museum completed its new $7.5 million west wing. "While we like to think that everyone will come to Baltimore to see the Cone Collection, we realize it's just not possible," said Arnold L. Lehman, the director of the Baltimore Museum. "Sending it to Houston is a wonderful opportunity to give a wider audience a chance to see the collection."

nytimes_articles.headline: Let's Introduce Some Common Sense Into Our Drug Policies; Ever-Present Threat
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   A. M. Rosenthal is to be commended for his efforts to keep the drug crisis deeply imbedded in the hearts and minds of every American ("Dismantling the War," column, May 18).

nytimes_articles.headline: Some Friends Fret as Clinton Is Slow in Choosing Envoys
nytimes_articles.abstract: Early this year, the White House asked two veteran Democrats whether they would like to be ambassador to Japan. Both of them said they would.   But President Clinton has not gotten around to making a choice. And now the two old friends and allies, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and Richard C. Holbrooke, a seasoned Asia hand, find themselves reluctant warriors in an unseemly contest that pits political eminence against diplomatic experience.

nytimes_articles.headline: Three-Star Cooking for Beginners
nytimes_articles.abstract: By the dawn's early light, an assortment of vegetables are being carefully whittled into edible oval gems in a basement kitchen of the Ritz Hotel. While the hotel's guests doze in downy luxury above, the sleepy-eyed staff on duty goes about its work with

nytimes_articles.headline: Draft Starts at Short, Then Stops on Mound
nytimes_articles.abstract: Major league clubs, reflecting the thirst for pitching that always abounds in an expansion year, drafted pitching, pitching and more pitching yesterday in the first round of the 1993 free agent amateur draft. Still, when it came to making the No. 1 choice, the Seattle Mariners, a club noted for developing talented young arms, went against the trend. The American League team instead chose one of the most highly touted position players to emerge from high school in years.   The choice was Alex Rodriguez, a 17-year-old shortstop out of Westminster Christian High School in Miami. Rodriguez is a 6-foot-3-inch, 190-pound right-handed hitter who is noted for both his power and speed. He batted .505 this season, hit 14 doubles, 9 home runs and stole 35 bases.

nytimes_articles.headline: With Aid, U.S. Seeks to Sway Ukraine on A-Arms
nytimes_articles.abstract: Reversing a strategy of using diplomatic pressure to persuade Ukraine to give up its nuclear weapons, the Clinton Administration is now trying to woo Kiev with promises of cooperation and economic support.   Les Aspin is to meet with Ukrainian officials in Kiev on Sunday, marking the first time that an American Defense Secretary will visit the capital. His visit follows one by Strobe Talbott, the United States Ambassador at Large to the former Soviet republics.

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Robert Mallary  Mitchell Algus Gallery 25 Thompson Street SoHo Through June 19   Robert Mallary, who is 76, first gained attention in the early 1960's for his Neo-Dadaist "junk" sculptures, wall reliefs made from materials he found in the streets of New York City. In the same decade he began to explore the field of computer graphics, then budding, with its potential for generating images through the manipulation of photographs of real and invented forms.

nytimes_articles.headline: Recipe for Diamond
nytimes_articles.abstract: Scientists at Penn State have found a way to whip up diamond, the hardest material on earth, by heating a plastic material in a conventional oven. The resulting low-grade material might afford a cheap way to coat large objects like airplane windshields with scratch-proof surfaces.     Article, page A14.

nytimes_articles.abstract: International A3-13  SOUTH AFRICA SETS ELECTION  The Government and most of South Africa's opposition parties settled tentatively on April 27, 1994 as the date when the country's black majority will cast their first votes. nytimes_articles.headline: Stop the Testing Now : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: The editorial "Halt Nuclear Tests" (May 26) gets it just right. To stop vertical and horizontal proliferation and strengthen the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, all nuclear testing must finally stop, and it must stop now. .Mexico and many ot

nytimes_articles.headline: In Trial's Wake, Rethinking What to Put in Quotes
nytimes_articles.abstract: As word spread yesterday about the Federal jury's findings in the New Yorker libel case, writers and editors disavowed the journalistic practices that were described at the trial and said these disclosures had tarnished journalism as a whole.   "I think it is always dangerous when the public is given any reason to doubt what they have been reading, especially in a magazine like The New Yorker, which has been famous for its accuracy," said James R. Gaines, managing editor of Time magazine, echoing the comments of other editors. Time itself was the subject of a celebrated 1985 libel case involving the Israeli Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon.

nytimes_articles.headline: Beefier Bradley Ready for Draft
nytimes_articles.abstract: SHAWN BRADLEY didn't want to talk about his pro prospects after flying more than 13 hours from Australia to put his 7-foot-6-inch frame up for grabs in this month's National Basketball Association draft.   Returning from a Mormon mission, Bradley was greeted at Salt Lake International Airport by some 75 to 100 friends, family and reporters.

nytimes_articles.headline: Critic's Choice/Comedy; New Kind of Arts Festival, With Laughs
nytimes_articles.abstract: Since comedy has become ubiquitous, thanks to cable television and a nationwide network of stand-up comedy clubs, it was only a matter of time before the form was celebrated in its own version of an international arts festival. The 10-day Toyota Comedy Festival, which continues through June 12, is a well-conceived series of 52 events, many free, that seriously attempts to take the measure of the field.    The festival, produced by Alan King and George Wein, will be spread out all over New York. Two Toyota Comedy Caravans of rising local comedians will travel around the city giving free performances at Seaside-Asser Levy Park in Brooklyn (4 P.M. tomorrow), Clove Lakes Park in Staten Island (4 P.M. tomorrow), Crotona Park in the Bronx (1 P.M. Sunday) and Forest Park in Queens (3 P.M. Sunday).

nytimes_articles.headline: Manufacturing Job Losses Cripple the Economy; Worst Isn't Over
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Re "New Jump in Inflation Rattles Markets" (Business Day, May 14): If the statements by some economists and law makers that recent statistics presage a return to inflation does not constitute sophistry, it borders on it.

nytimes_articles.headline: Reviews/Film; A Former Child Star Managing Stars-to-Be
nytimes_articles.abstract: Former child star still pitching. Tireless Fox keeps the comedy afloat.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gift of the Heart
nytimes_articles.abstract: Music by Chopin, Liszt, Bach and Richard Strauss, as well as folk music and cabaret, are on the program tomorrow night at a concert to benefit Gift of the Heart -- Insight Seminar, an annual event for people with life-threatening illnesses. The concert begins at 7:30 P.M. at the Christ and St. Stephen's Church, 120 West 69th Street. Tickets may be bought at the door; suggested contribution is $15.

nytimes_articles.headline: On Stage, and Off
nytimes_articles.abstract: Like a couple of evenly matched heavyweights, the two top-nominated musicals will go head to head on Sunday night when the Tony Awards are announced on CBS, and, not surprisingly, the debate over which will wear the ultimate crown -- "Kiss of the Spider Woman" or "Tommy" -- has dominated a week of speculation.   Interviews with some two dozen of the 668 Tony voters, and a few well-informed nonvoters (all were guaranteed anonymity) indicated that the two shows, each of which garnered 11 nominations, were in a dead heat for the best-musical award and that otherwise a division of the spoils is likely. Many agree that the best-musical award could go to one and best director to the other. One prediction -- call it the necessary-but-not-sufficient theory -- espoused by Rocco Landesman, the president of Jujamcyn Theaters, is this: Because the Broadway musical tradition revolves around a good story, "Kiss" isn't likely to win best musical without winning best book. And because the pleasure of "Tommy" is so tied to its fantastical staging, it isn't likely to win best musical without winning best director. Terrence McNally's book could win, he added, and "Kiss" could still lose; ditto for Des McAnuff's direction and "Tommy."

nytimes_articles.headline: Sounds Around Town
nytimes_articles.abstract: Remembering Sun Ra   Sun Ra Tribute, Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 228-6300. Sun Ra will be remembered this weekend in a club that played a big part in his revival during the mid-1970's. If all goes well, his big band will make its boss's ascent back to Saturn a joyous occasion. There are two shows tomorrow, at 8 and 11 P.M. The cover charge is $12.50.  Boukman Eksperyans    Boukman Eksperyans, S.O.B.'s, 204 Varick Street, South Village, (212) 243-4940. The best of the young Haitian bands in the city, Boukman Eksperyans mixes old-style Haitian compas with modern Caribbean music, along with carnival and voudon rhythms. The group is exciting, and traditional, and pure pop. The shows tonight start at 11 P.M. and 1 A.M. Tickets are $16. Conjunto Imagen    Conjunto Imagen, New Music Cafe, 285 West Broadway, at Canal Street, TriBeCa, (212) 941-1019. The conjunto sound has been overlooked in salsa recently, which is too bad because the style grooves deeply. Conjunto Imagen is one of the best groups working in New York City, and their shows always rock, with tight horns and percussion working over and around the metallic, percussive ostinatos of the guitarlike tres. Shows are tonight at 9:30 and midnight, and there is a $7.50 cover charge.  P. W.

nytimes_articles.headline: YOUTH JOBLESSNESS IS AT RECORD HIGH
nytimes_articles.abstract: Unemployment among New York City's teen-agers rose to 40 percent in the first three months this year, the city said yesterday. It was nearly double the rate of two years ago and the worst in the 25 years that records have been kept.   The sharp increase indicated that the long recession has had an especially severe impact on young job seekers. "Our young people used to be on the bottom of the list -- now they are not even on the list," said John Bess, executive director of the Manhattan Valley Youth Program, a nonprofit group that helps teen-agers find work.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Israel, Peace Builds a Consensus
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   It is uncommon for more than two days to pass without seeing an article in your newspaper reporting deaths or injuries to Palestinians in the Gaza Strip. Occasionally, your reports include Jews in Israel who have been stabbed as well. These are usually factual matters, not open to dispute, except to determine whether the actions of the Palestinians were sufficient to justify a lethal response from the Israeli Army, or if the Israeli Army exceeded reasonable boundaries in using deadly force.

nytimes_articles.headline: Finding the Rhythm of the Road, at 10 Miles an Hour
nytimes_articles.abstract: I SING the body exhausted.    Dehydrated and jelly-legged, sunburned and sweat-grimy, I'd been bicycling the road from Boston since dawn and had spent a big part of the warm afternoon on unexpectedly vertical terrain in northeastern Connecticut. New York City, my final destination, seemed as distant as China. And for an hour, ever since Union, Conn., (the gateway to Nipmuck State Forest, an extremely popular place among black flies), I'd been saying two words in my head, over and over, repeating them like a mantra: Stafford Springs, Stafford Springs, Stafford Springs.   In college, there'd been a guy who lived on my hall whose hometown was Stafford Springs, Conn. I didn't know him at all, don't know what happened to him, but 20 years later, huffing and puffing through the pretty hills of nowhere, I conjured him up, remembered him as an affluent sort. And putting that memory together with the bold print with which the town was emblazoned on my wrinkled Connecticut road map, I concluded: there will be a motel in Stafford Springs. There will be an excellent restaurant there.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Piano; Undaunted By Inimitable Predecessor
nytimes_articles.abstract: There was probably a bit of hubris at work when Mordecai Shehori titled his concert at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday night "A Tribute to Vladimir Horowitz." When it comes to pianism, the only possible tribute to Horowitz is in one of his recordings. Who else could convincingly combine nearly inaudible pianissimos and thunderous exclamations in a single phrase? Or, with an almost childlike fascination, seductively toy with inner voices or twisting rhythms? Or create a brittle yet truly singing fortissimo?    But Mr. Shehori was undaunted by the challenge. He programmed music that was meant to recall Horowitz's achievements and even offered a performance of a piece that Horowitz composed when he was 14 years old: the Etude-Fantasy in E flat ("Les Vagues"). And there were times when Mr. Shehori almost managed to suggest, in a distant, slightly fuzzy fashion, the Horowitz style of pianism.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Agency to Review Case Of Scientist on Hunger Strike
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Department of Health and Human Services will review the case of Walter Stewart, the National Institutes of Health scientist who is in the 25th day of a hunger strike to protest the halting of his investigations of scientific misconduct.   Dr. Audrey Manley, the Acting Assistant Secretary for Health, phoned Mr. Stewart, 48, and his co-worker, Dr. Ned Feder, 65 and pleaded for an end to the hunger strike while the department looked into their contentions that they had been treated unfairly. The investigation will be conducted by Harriet Rabb, the department's general counsel.

nytimes_articles.headline: Russia Finance Chief Tells of Enemies Within
nytimes_articles.abstract: Providing an extraordinarily frank glimpse of struggles in the Government to stabilize the economy, the Finance Minister directed criticism tonight at his Cabinet colleagues, at the persistence of "pseudo-Soviet thinking" and at the "financial tourism" of Western business executives who visit but do not invest.   The official, Boris G. Fyodorov, 35, is considered the leading economic reformer in the Government and the most tireless proponent of financial and monetary discipline. But he described a Government in which his small band of Westernized economists are fighting a constant battle against colleagues who wish to restore many of the plans and price controls of the Soviet era, in which they were trained.

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jutta Koether  Pat Hearn Gallery 39 Wooster Street SoHo Through June 26   Jutta Koether, a 35-year-old artist from Germany who has spent much of the last two years in New York City, is one of several women helping to breathe new life into painting. In two-dimensional works, as well as in performance and installation pieces, the artist has seemed to circle painting from a somewhat ironic distance; in this exhibition, she gets down to work.

nytimes_articles.headline: Knicks Are Somber, Subdued, Shocked
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Knicks departed for Chicago today, perhaps headed for the end of their season.   To avoid elimination Friday night in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals, New York must somehow regroup quickly from its most devastating loss of the playoffs. With Wednesday night's dramatic 97-94 victory, the Chicago Bulls moved a step closer toward winning a third consecutive National Basketball Association championship. Meanwhile, the Knicks remained a team in shock today, shaken by losing such a crucial game during the final frustrating seconds.

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton and Powell Discover That They Need Each Other
nytimes_articles.abstract: It was during the transition, and President George Bush, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, were sitting around the Oval Office with some aides, musing about Bill Clinton and the merry band of baby boomers about to storm the White House.   Mr. Bush and Mr. Cheney were teasing General Powell with the ease of friends who had been through wars together, one participant in the meeting recalls. "Well, Colin, you're going to have to deal with these guys now," Mr. Bush said. "Not for long," General Powell replied with raised eyebrows as the others let out a hearty laugh. Matter of Mutual Survival    Indeed, when Bill Clinton took office, General Powell already had one eye on the exit, considering retirement even earlier than his currently planned departure in September. Since then, though, the two men have developed an intriguing relationship, one that neither of them could have expected.

nytimes_articles.headline: N.B.A.'s Latest Serial: Superman vs. the Cult
nytimes_articles.abstract: So now we have to make the choice: Do we want Superman or the Cult? Do we want to fly toward summer with Michael Jordan, his rakish dog tongue loose as he clicks into overdrive, clears a runway, lifts off and leaves us breathless or do we want to hang with the Knicks, this nineties version of "Father Knows Best," call it Coach Dad and the Posse?   No answers here, only more questions. Is Superman dying, worn down by this longest of all basketball seasons, from the fall of 1991 through the spring of 1993, two National Basketball Association campaigns bridged by a Dream Team dalliance? Or is he toying with us, unrolling the suspense for his own amusement and the box office? Is Jordan's gambling the controlled passion of a man whose avocation also is competition, or is it out of bounds, needing further investigation by a game that has never completely outjumped its old scandals?

nytimes_articles.headline: Abroad at Home; Anatomy Of a Smear
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a speech last year, Lani Guinier said she hoped that South Africa would move toward majority rule -- modified to assure participation by the white minority. Only a coalition government including whites, she said, would have the legitimacy needed in a new South Africa.   Is that the same Lani Guinier, nominee to be Assistant Attorney General, who was dumped by President Clinton after the political right painted her as some kind of black racist? Yes, it is. How can that be?

nytimes_articles.headline: Ain't Nothing but a Draft Pick
nytimes_articles.abstract: They call his cousin Elvis the king of rock 'n' roll. Kirk Presley can only hope to be king of the hill every fifth day. The Mets are offering him that chance, having drafted the 18-year-old right-hander from Tupelo, Miss., in the first round yesterday.   Kirk Presley, who was only 2 1/2 when his famous third cousin died, did not know Elvis, but he has known his shadow: public-address systems serenaded him with the song, "Elvis Is Dead" throughout his high-school career.

nytimes_articles.headline: Decent Germans Need More Muscle and Less Fear
nytimes_articles.abstract: Again people have been burned to death in a German city. Again they were targeted only because they were foreigners, although some had lived in Germany for decades or been born there. Again come the declarations of shock, disgust and anger from German po

nytimes_articles.headline: Restaurants
nytimes_articles.abstract: Like a long-running Broadway show, Orso has remained vital and fresh despite many cast changes over the years. This offshoot of the Joe Allen empire opened in 1985 when Restaurant Row on West 46th Street seemed headed toward gastronomic senescence. Almost single-handedly, Orso brought back the Broadway movers and shakers, instilling new life into the block.   Orso's step-down main dining room is dominated by a high arching skylight that creates a cheerful, sunny setting at lunch; in the evening it creates a sense of spaciousness. Soft ocher tones and wood trim contribute to a casual, contemporary setting. Walls are covered with publicity photographs of sports and entertainment celebrities. In the back an open tile-and-steel kitchen churns out pizzas, pastas and appealing grilled fare.

nytimes_articles.headline: Builder of Parade Floats Puts World on Wheels
nytimes_articles.abstract: IF IT'S Friday, this must be Bob DeVito's garage, where the parade floats go when they are not rolling along some avenue somewhere. Memorial Day, Wayne, N.J. Tomorrow, Montclair, N.J. Sunday, the Bronx. Next week, Fifth Avenue.   Mr. DeVito's garage, on a long street of warehouses and old factories, is like a back lot in Hollywood, but on wheels. Somewhere in this Styrofoam-and-papier-mache fantasy land, he's got the whole world on a float. New York to Moscow? It only takes a few seconds when the ocean is globs of blue paint.

nytimes_articles.headline: Russian Male Choir
nytimes_articles.abstract: Akafist, an 18-voice male chamber choir from Moscow, will give a concert on Sunday at 4 P.M. at Trinity Church, Broadway at Wall Street in lower Manhattan. On the program are Russian folk songs and sacred music from the Russian Orthodox Church. Tickets are $15 and $20. Information: (212) 602-0873.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: When LEANZA CORNETT was crowned Miss America 1993 in September, she vowed to talk about AIDS at her appearances during the year. Since then, she has learned that not everyone wants her to talk about the disease, in particular not to schoolchildren.    On Tuesday, for example, she was scheduled to speak at three elementary schools and one high school in Bradford County in north central Florida. But a week ago, she said, "I received a letter saying that the school board had asked I not mention the word AIDS or talk about it or sex, but that I talk only about self-esteem and saying no to drugs."

nytimes_articles.headline: Let's Introduce Some Common Sense Into Our Drug Policies
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Some drug legalization proponents suggest that anyone who opposes legalization must support all the foolish and ineffective drug-war policies pursued by the last two administrations: eradication of foreign drug crops, massive spending to interdict drug smuggling and draconian sentences for minor-league drug dealers.   It is strange to find A. M. Rosenthal in "Dismantling the War" (column, May 18) using the same twisted logic to argue that anyone, even the Attorney General, who opposes foolish and ineffective drug-war policies must support drug legalization. Not so.

nytimes_articles.headline: Perot Parades a Republican But Is Mum on Endorsement
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ross Perot's Texas organization called a news conference today, put Mr. Perot and Kay Bailey Hutchison, the Republican Senate candidate, on the same stage, and announced its members' support for her in the election on Saturday. Then the organization took pains to emphasize that this was not an endorsement of her.   Bill Walker, the Texas director of United We Stand America Inc., said the announcement that the group's members were supporting Mrs. Hutchison was based on a questionnaire mailed to the Texas membership of the group that Mr. Perot formed after his independent bid for President last year.

nytimes_articles.headline: Plastic Goes in the Oven and Diamond Comes Out
nytimes_articles.abstract: By cooking plastic in an ordinary oven, scientists at Pennsylvania State University seem to have achieved the chemical equivalent of making a silk purse out of a sow's ear: They have made a form of diamond.   Whether their instant diamond mix proves to have practical uses, the scientists believe they have hit upon a novel method for arranging the carbon atoms in a polymer that mimics the carbon structure of crystalline diamond. When this polymer is cooked at a relatively low temperature, it is largely converted to diamond.

nytimes_articles.headline: Musty Academic Speculation or Blueprint for Political Action?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Historically, most law review articles are neither little noted nor long remembered, except by the professors who wrote them and the committees who control their futures.   But twice in six years, Presidential nominations have foundered over esoteric academic writings. The articles written by Lani Guinier about the Voting Rights Act caused her political death. In the failed nomination of Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court, they were merely a contributing factor.

nytimes_articles.headline: Laoretti Is Struggling To Regain His Stroke
nytimes_articles.abstract: Larry Laoretti went from club pro to overnight hero last year when he scored his first victory on the Senior PGA Tour in the Senior United States Open.    Laoretti, from Mahopac, N.Y., played pretty well for about a month after his triumph, but his game has since declined. In 14 events this season, Laoretti's best finish has been a tie for 10th at the Bell Atlantic Classic, two weeks ago.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Day at Bergdorf's Just for the Fun of It
nytimes_articles.abstract: I MISS the violets on the Bonwit Teller bag. Not to mention the three-tiered Lenox candy dishes B. Altman used to sell. Go ahead, scoff. No one even eats candy anymore. But in this era of diminishing department stores, I'm feeling sentimental.   I know I'm partly to blame for their demise. Like millions of other people, I've become a devoted catalogue shopper, ordering everything by phone, from dishes to shoes. On Saturday afternoons, the last thing I want to do is fight the midtown crowds. Once you learn to shop lying down, it's too hard to get up again.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Libel law is about providing compensation for damages to one's reputation. It's not about punishing journalists for not adhering to the highest standards of their profession. The danger is you are turning libel trials into some kind of journalism ethics tribunal." -- JANE E. KIRTLEY, executive director of the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press.  [ A16:3. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: Cherokee Run Draws Rail for A Big Belmont
nytimes_articles.abstract: Twenty years after her legendary colt, Secretariat, won the Belmont Stakes by 31 lengths, Penny Tweedy fished into the silver bowl yesterday and drew the numbered chips that assigned post positions for the 125th running of the Belmont Stakes tomorrow. She handed the first number to Bruce Lombardi, the racing secretary, who announced: "No. 1 post. Cherokee Run."   That was fine with Cherokee Run, a speed horse who would now be able to spring from the starting gate and rocket straight ahead while everybody else scrambled to catch him or at least crowd him on the rail. And, if he could keep rocketing for a mile and a half, which is a pretty big "if," then he might just make some racing history by winning the $500,000 Belmont Stakes, the third and most demanding race in the Triple Crown series.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Solingen Tragedy
nytimes_articles.abstract: Only days after the Bonn Parliament yielded to pressure from the right by scrapping Germany's liberal asylum laws, extremists stepped up their campaign against foreigners. Five Turkish women and children died in a firebombing ascribed to neo-Nazi skinheads. The Solingen tragedy, the worst of its kind since unification in 1990, ignited violent demonstrations by Turkish immigrants. Yet Chancellor Helmut Kohl's generalized condemnation of all violence does not begin to deal with the valid grievances of a vulnerable minority.   Germany's 1.5 million or so Turkish inhabitants are not asylum-seekers fleeing persecution at home. Nearly all are guest workers, or the offspring of guest workers, whose toil has been an essential element in Germany's "economic miracle." However, few are citizens, hardly any are civil servants and none sit in the national Parliament.

nytimes_articles.headline: Where Is Kohl When the Victims Need Him?
nytimes_articles.abstract: When the firebombing of a foreigners' residence in the German city of Solingen claimed the lives of five Turkish women, the German public and most politicians responded spontaneously. .Within hours of the cowardly attack on Saturday, Germans joined han

nytimes_articles.headline: Sounds Around Town
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jeff Harnar on Hollywood   Jeff Harnar, "Dancing in the Dark: Vincente Minnelli's Hollywood," the Oak Room at the Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, Manhattan, (212) 840-6800. In a show that is a model of its type, Jeff Harnar pays tribute to the celebrated movie director by blending biographical anecdotes with astutely chosen songs from the 14 movie musicals Minnelli directed. A smooth pop baritone who suggests a hybrid of Larry Kert and Johnny Mathis, Mr. Harnar hits a peak in a rock-and-roll-flavored medley of songs with celestial themes. Show time is 9:30 tonight and tomorrow. At the club's 11:30 P.M. late shows, Mr. Harnar is also performing his equally delightful program "The 1959 Broadway Songbook." For each show there is a $25 music charge and a $10 food-and-drink minimum.  The Three Faces of Betty    Betty, the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, Chelsea, (212) 244-3005. A musical-comedy trio featuring Alyson Palmer and the sisters Amy and Bitzy Ziff, Betty is as smart and funny as it is stylistically uncategorizable. Short sketches, commentary and news media satire with a feminist slant are blended with original songs into a continuous stream of music and talk. The musical elements include cello, train whistle, bass and electric keyboard. Performance art meets cabaret meets rock with a hint of funk. Show times are tonight and tomorrow at 9 and 11:15, and tickets are $25 and $20.

nytimes_articles.headline: 3 Candidates Striving to Leave No Republican Unturned
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jim Wallwork came here to greet noontime shoppers and noshers around the Morristown Green today at a campaign stop that showed the difficulties of winning votes in the Republican primary for governor.   He shook the hands of Democrats. He shook the hands of independents. He even shook the hands of a few of New Jersey's 799,000 Republicans, who make up only about 20 percent of the state's 3.9 million registered voters.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the sale of the Circle K Corporation misstated the number of creditor groups that supported the company's bankruptcy reorganization plan. Three groups will receive payments under the plan -- bank lenders, noteholders and unsecured creditors.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Spoken Word
nytimes_articles.abstract: "WOMEN IN FILM: YOU GO GIRLS!" Flatbush and DeKalb Avenues, Flatbush, Brooklyn. A panel discussion featuring Julie Dash, the director of "Daughters of the Dust"; the producer Grace Blake, the actress Joie Lee and others, part of the Spike Lee 40 Acres Film Institute lecture series. Saturday at 11 A.M. Admission: $25; $15 for college students; $10 for high school students. Information: (718) 858-9620. READING, Way of Action, 316 Seventh Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn. Sixteen poets and fiction writers read from their work in a benefit for the Brooklyn Bound Reading Series. Sunday at 3 P.M. Admission: $7. Information: (718) 965-1541.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article in Business Day yesterday about the General Motors Corporation's leasing of used cars and trucks misstated the Chrysler Corporation's leasing strategy. Chrysler does not offer leasing on used vehicles. The article also misidentified a G.M. financing plan for car purchases. The plan is known as Smartbuy.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Referendum on Guns : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "For Japan, Acquittal Confirms Worst View of U.S." (May 25): .The death of Yoshihiro Hattori must be incomprehensible to his parents and friends, indeed to all Japanese people. I am an American and I don't understand it. I hope and

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dario Urzay  Pamela Auchincloss Gallery 558 Broadway (near Prince Street) SoHo Through June 30   Sealed beneath shiny layers of varnish, pale clouds of color drift across Dario Urzay's canvases. Mr. Urzay, a Spanish painter who lives in New York City, uses cosmetics as pigments, and as a result his palette runs to pastel pinks, pale greens and tawny browns with a few fiery reds and metallic golds thrown in.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hard-Hit Military Contractors Plead for Loans
nytimes_articles.abstract: With economists predicting continued decline for Long Island's military industry, a group representing more than 100 Defense Department subcontractors yesterday implored Federal and state officials to help them find the money to convert their companies to peacetime operations.   Without an infusion of cash, in the form of low-cost loans from banks and Government agencies, small and medium-sized companies that have long depended on military contracts will be unable to compete for commercial contracts and will close their doors, leaders of the newly formed group say. They say that during the last 18 months Long Island subcontractors seeking commercial business would have won $500 million in contracts if they had had the money to finance startup work.

nytimes_articles.headline: Good With Violins, Not With People
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Un Coeur en Hiver" ("A Heart in Winter"), a coolly elegant romance directed by Claude Sautet, is centered on Stephane (Daniel Auteuil), who is solemn and expert when it comes to his craft (repairing fine violins) but has no skill in matters of emotion.    There is a certain irony to this film's title. Stephane is hardly more wintry-hearted than the story's other two principals, with whom he becomes involved in a subtle and difficult romantic triangle. Each of these refined, self-involved characters has his or her own form of chilly isolation, but it is Stephane who pays most noticeably for his shortcomings.

nytimes_articles.headline: Backing Away Again, Christopher Says Bosnia Is Not a Vital Interest
nytimes_articles.abstract: Taking another step back from the war in Bosnia, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today that the conflict "involves our humanitarian concerns, but it does not involve our vital interests."   The end of the cold war, Mr. Christopher said, has changed the stakes in such conflicts and is a primary reason the Clinton Administration has failed to persuade its European allies to follow its lead on Bosnia.

nytimes_articles.headline: Raiders to Rocket: Let's Talk
nytimes_articles.abstract: Toronto Argonauts receiver RAGHIB (ROCKET) ISMAIL will be in California this weekend to meet with Los Angeles Raiders' officials and work out for the team's coaching staff.   "We haven't talked about a specific amount or the number of years," said BOB WOOLF, Ismail's agent. "But if they like him and they put forth an offer that I like, then anything is possible."

nytimes_articles.headline: TV Weekend; An Uneasy Pair: Business and Politics
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Washington Under the Influence" is the first of four programs on the uneasy relationship between business and politics. Evidently under the influence of the admirable Fred Friendly seminars, the new series, "On the Issues," brings together players from Government, corporate board rooms and elsewhere to be badgered by an immoderate sort of moderator about a hypothetical problem that reflects problems that are only too real.   Tonight's hypothetical, advanced by Jeff Greenfield of ABC News, has to do with a small furniture company that is under attack by workers and environmentalists for using chemicals that cause chronic fatigue syndrome. Lending themselves to the exercise are lobbyists, legislators, business executives and journalists, generously lumped together by John Chancellor, who introduces each hour, as "distinguished leaders."

nytimes_articles.headline: 20 Years After, Foreman Is Again Stalking a Title
nytimes_articles.abstract: George Foreman stopped sparring long enough to give a lesson in syntax. He was surprised at reports he would retire after his fight Monday against Tommy Morrison for the vacant World Boxing Organization heavyweight crown.   "I only said, 'This will probably be the last time you'll see me in the ring,' " Foreman said. He paused, and added, "But I never said I was going to retire."

nytimes_articles.headline: Man in the News; The Mercurial Prince: Norodom Sihanouk
nytimes_articles.abstract: He was a King when he was 18, a prisoner at 20, an exile at 31, a Prime Minister at 32, a chief of state again at 38, a prisoner again at 54, an exile again at 69.   Now, at 70, Norodom Sihanouk has once again come to the brink of power, and characertistically pulled back, at least for the moment. His approach to the situation appears to be not much different from what it was in the days when his business cards simply said, "Sihanouk du Cambodge," Sihanouk of Cambodia.

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Richard Prince  Barbara Gladstone Gallery 99 Greene Street (near Prince Street) SoHo Through June 12   The women in Richard Prince's blowups of snapshots taken from motorcycle magazines are both creepy and pathetic. Draping themselves nude over the seats of their boyfriends' bikes or posing in dark glasses and leopardskin tights, they seem to want to embody defiant fantasies of sexual outrageousness.
