pages.abstract: The Holbeck Hall Hotel was a clifftop hotel in Scarborough, North Yorkshire, England, owned by the Turner family. It was built in 1879 by George Alderson Smith as a private residence, and was later converted to a hotel.

pages.title: Scarborough, North Yorkshire
pages.abstract: Scarborough is a seaside town in the district and county of North Yorkshire, England. With a population of 61,749, Scarborough is the largest town on the Yorkshire Coast and the fourth-largest settlement in the county.

nytimes_articles.headline: When Rehabilitation Is the Patient's Goal
nytimes_articles.abstract:
BOB CICCONE bent forward as he pressed against the padded bar of a machine designed to put him through a range of motion exercises. Although the effort was causing him some discomfort, he was ecstatic. "I went to several other places, and they were all a waste of time," he explained. "This facility is a lifesaver. This is state of the art." 

Mr. Ciccone, a retired building contractor from Glastonbury who was injured in a car accident three years ago, travels twice a week to Gaylord Hospital in Wallingford for physical therapy. His enthusiasm was directed not only at the outpatient program but also at the handsome new building into which it has just moved.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jodi Lynn Roth, A. J. Wasserstein
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Roth of Fair Lawn, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jodi Lynn Roth to Adam J. Wasserstein, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Wasserstein of New York and New Preston, Conn. A December wedding is planned.   Ms. Roth, 26, is a graduate of Tufts University and a candidate for a master's degree in public and private management at Yale University. Her father is a certified public accountant in Hackensack, N.J. Her mother, Barbara Roth, is a sales associate at the Nordstrom department store in Paramus, N.J.

nytimes_articles.headline: Photography That Is Immune From the 'Romance' of Labor
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT seems to be getting closer, the utopian heaven in which machines do all the work, leaving people free, as it were, to produce art or go sport fishing. Yet, to judge from Sebastiao Salgado's photographs at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, hard labor is still the lot of the majority.    At the port of Chittagong, in Bangladesh, for instance, there are beached ships to be demolished manually by blowtorch and sledgehammer. In Java, livings are made harvesting sulfur from the lake boiling in the crater of a volcano. But with the seven-hour climb up to the crater and the return trip loaded down with 155 pounds of the mineral, not to mention the fumes encountered on the way, each gleaner has to rest two days for every one worked.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wildflowers Gaining in State's Esteem
nytimes_articles.abstract:
"WAKE UP, Connecticut, it's time to catch up with what's going on in the rest of the nation!" That warning was given recently by the director of the Connecticut Arboretum at Connecticut College in New London, Bill Niering, who spoke to the American Bird Association and Associated Field Ornithologists. The management of the state's roadsides was on his mind. He challenged the gathering "to put pressure on your political representatives to restore the narrow mowed edges alongside Connecticut's highways" to the self-sustaining meadows and fields of yesteryear.
Black-Eyed Susans and Wild Carrot

 "We could mow our roadsides just once a year and have field habitats for our declining field birds," said Mr. Niering, a professor of botany, in his laboratory afterwards. "We could have black-eyed Susans, wild carrot, knappweed, blue-stem grasses, yarrow, milkweed, coreopsis! Look at Texas; they have miles of beautiful wildflowers!"

nytimes_articles.headline: A Victorian Jewel That's Also a Mine for Musical Theater
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHEN the announcement was made to preserve rather than demolish the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam in 1959, Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff declared: "This to me is very important for the country's soul."    A whirl of musicales, soirees and benefits of all sorts, even plaster ripping parties, followed for the purpose of raising the $500,000 required to restore the many splendored showplace, then being used by the State Highway Department as a storage depot. And for the four years it took to complete, the restoration of the four-story Opry House -- a frequent spelling at the time it was built in 1876 -- on the banks of the Connecticut River was the talk of eastern Connecticut. Sightseers paid 50 cents for a tour of the work in progress on Saturdays between 2 and 4 P.M. By varying accounts, about twice the amount needed for the restoration came in, and the reopening of Goodspeed, a victory for esthetics and for civilization, took place on June 18, 1963. And the show that marked its rebirth in Victorian splendor was "Oh Lady! Lady!" by Jerome Kern.

nytimes_articles.headline: With First Pick, Magic Having Interviews
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Orlando Magic screened another prospective No. 1 National Basketball Association draft pick Friday, interviewing Memphis State's 6-foot-8-inch all-America guard, ANFERNEE HARDAWAY.

nytimes_articles.headline: Debra Abrams, Jonathan Gamza
nytimes_articles.abstract: Debra Gail Abrams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Abrams of Marlboro, N.J., was married last evening to Jonathan Ross Gamza, the son of Peggy Gamza of Marlboro and Leon Gamza of Cliffside Park, N.J. Rabbi Donald Weber performed the ceremony at the Livingston (N.J.) Country Club.   Mrs. Gamza, 24, is an account executive at Warwick, Baker & Fiore, an advertising agency in New York. She and her husband graduated from Syracuse University, she cum laude and he magna cum laude. The bride's parents own Junior Tours Inc., a student travel company in Old Bridge, N.J.

nytimes_articles.headline: Half and Half Means Well Rounded
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   For the past 13 years, I've referred to my children as "half-black, half-Jewish." Miriam Bieder (Letters, May 16) observes that I've been incorrect when describing my children in that way since black refers to race and Jewish refers to religion.

nytimes_articles.headline: Peter Pucci and Ellen Sirot
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ellen Sirot, a hand model and a modern dancer with Peter Pucci Plus Dancers in New York, was married yesterday to Mr. Pucci, the company's artistic director. Dr. Robert Berson, the leader of the Ethical Culture Society of Northern Westchester, officiated at the home of the bride's mother in Greenwich, Conn.   Ms. Sirot, who is keeping her name, graduated from Barnard College. She is a daughter of Margaret Sirot and the late Marvin Sirot. Her father was the founder and president of the Round Hill Group, a pension investment concern in Greenwich.

nytimes_articles.headline: Another Case Of Double Vision
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Consider this scenario: A carefully selected double fills in for a leader at a public ceremony. When the leader has a stroke, the impersonation is extended. A subordinate and the double clash and the subordinate leaves, only to accuse the double of crimes at a press conference. A simulated stroke is planned for the switch back to "reality." The woman who loved the leader ends up in love with the double.

nytimes_articles.headline: Catterson Under Fire Again Over Seized Car
nytimes_articles.abstract:
ALONG the way to becoming the most colorful and perhaps controversial elected official in Suffolk County, District Attorney James M. Catterson Jr. converted a BMW sports sedan seized from a convicted drug dealer into his personal work car.

For Mr. Catterson, a Republican who announced last month that he would seek a second four-year term, driving that car sends a highly visible message that his office is tough on drug traffickers and is quick to use asset-seizure laws to confiscate their property. But with criticism mounting against Federal and state laws that critics say have turned prosecutors into bounty hunters, Mr. Catterson's defense of the seizure policy is emerging as an issue in the November election.

nytimes_articles.headline: GUATEMALA IS NEAR CHOICE FOR LEADER
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a move to end the most serious political crisis in Guatemala's seven years of civilian rule, Congress was close tonight to choosing the Government's human rights ombudsman as the country's new President.   The ombudsman, Ramiro de Leon Carpio, 51, would finish out the term of Jorge Serrano Elias, who was overthrown by the military last Tuesday, one week after he dissolved Congress and the Supreme Court and suspended the Constitution. Mr. Serrano was to leave office in January 1996.

nytimes_articles.headline: Streetscapes: The Thalia Theater; A Restoration for a Threatened Parabolic Curiosity
nytimes_articles.abstract: NO, no -- this is all backwards. Small movie revival houses on development sites are supposed to be demolished, not survive, and certainly not be restored.    But that's what's happening to the 1931 Thalia Theater, at 95th Street and Broadway, which is scheduled to reopen June 18 after six dark years. New and old patrons will see the unusual Art Moderne design, the ticket counter, lounge and tile work brushed up, and be able to judge whether the radically different tilted floor is a gimmick or an innovation.

nytimes_articles.headline: John Carney Jr. and Tracey Quillen
nytimes_articles.abstract: Tracey Tatem Quillen, a special assistant in Washington to Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, was married yesterday to John Charles Carney Jr., the deputy chief administrative officer for New Castle County, Del. The Rev. John Hopkins officiated at Holy Rosary Roman Catholic Church in Claymont, Del. The Rev. Ralph R. Johnson Jr., a Presbyterian minister, took part in the ceremony.   Ms. Quillen, 30, is keeping her name. She is a summa cum laude graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Tatem Quillen of New Castle, Del.

nytimes_articles.headline: On Sunday; What's Humor To One Brings Pain to Another
nytimes_articles.abstract: NORA Weinerth is an advocate for the mentally ill, a co-founder of the New York-based National Stigma Clearinghouse. Last fall she received complaints about Doug Marlette's Kudzu comic strip, and soon after issued a Stigma Busters Alert, accusing Mr. Marlette of "flippant treatment of depression, euthanasia and suicide in over a dozen strips."   She has scored many stigma-busting coups. She persuaded the John Deere company to stop ads on "the world's first schizophrenic lawn mower." She wrote, "Why is it that schizophrenia is fair game for comedians in a way that cancer, AIDS and drug addiction are not?" Clarion Car Audio killed its "A Lot of Good an Airbag Will Do You If You Go Insane" campaign. Others capitulating include Nike sneakers, Wordstar software, Planters foods.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.N. Starts Plans for Bosnia Force Tomorrow
nytimes_articles.abstract: Senior peacekeeping officials, in a special meeting on Monday, will ask the five co-sponsors of a new Security Council resolution on Bosnia what troops, weapons and money they will provide to protect the designated safe havens for Muslims.   The resolution, passed on Friday, would require as many as 25,000 troops backed by artillery and attack helicopters, senior United Nations officials said. That preliminary estimate is far higher than the force of 5,000 to 10,000 that some diplomats had said might be sufficient.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Zaire, Leaders Still Prey on the Led
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Having lived in Kinshasa, Zaire, from 1989 through 1991, I follow your all-to-rare reporting from there with intense interest. "In Zaire, Starvation Is Growing in a Wealthy Land" (news article, May 16) struck a nerve.   The observation that "acute food problems facing Zaire appear self-inflicted" risks pointing the finger in the wrong direction; self-inflicted and Government-inflicted are not the same, especially in a country where those in power are accountable to no one. The overwhelming majority of Zairians have had virtually nothing to do with causing the problems they face daily. The practice of blaming the victim is in this case, as in any case, inappropriate and destructive.

nytimes_articles.headline: My Son, The Rocket
nytimes_articles.abstract: HOW do you solve a problem like David Leslie?   You can't really blame the downtown "stunt artist," who also refers to himself as an "impact addict," for not telling his parents about his performance pieces. Whose parents, after all, would want to hear about how their son flew himself, in a homemade rocket, over a mountain of watermelons on Broome Street in 1985? Whose parents would want to hear how their son "exploded himself" as a human firecracker on the streets of Chinatown in 1986, or about the fight he staged with Riddick Bowe, now the heavyweight champion, on the Staten Island Ferry in 1987?

nytimes_articles.headline: The Forbidden Books of Youth
nytimes_articles.abstract: What was the first "forbidden" book you read and what were the circumstances under which you read it? The editors of the Book Review asked 14 men and women to share their secrets of fantasies inspired, expectations dashed, wisdom gained and the lonely knowledge that only comes in the dead of night with a flashlight in hand and a head under the covers. Here are the responses. Elmore Leonard    In the seventh or eighth grade a friend of mine who also read books told me that "Anthony Adverse," by Hervey Allen, had dirty parts in it; and I remember looking but don't recall if I found any. It's not that I was forbidden to read the novel -- it was on the shelf at home, I think a Book-of-the-Month-Club selection -- but I did probably look through it on the sly, making the act feel forbidden.

nytimes_articles.headline: Like Caesar, Clinton Gets No Praise
nytimes_articles.abstract: At the 20th Street Cafe, where biscuits and gravy costs $1.99 and political banter is dished out for free, customers this morning were grousing about Bill Clinton as if they had been given the wrong plate of breakfast.   "This wasn't the guy we voted for," said Gilbert Castellano, a 59-year-old postal worker, as he leaned over a steaming cup of coffee. "What happened to the old Bill Clinton?"

nytimes_articles.headline: School Bill Is Viewed Many Ways
nytimes_articles.abstract: The State Senate gave final approval on Friday to legislation that requires every community in Connecticut to discuss the desegregation of public schools across town lines, but even in the last hours of debate, the expectations of what might result from those talks varied wildly.   Through the distorted glass of race politics, the opponents of the bill expect -- or fear -- the most from it, while many of the legislators who voted for it did so because they expect very little.

nytimes_articles.headline: What It Simply Takes to Be Simply Chic
nytimes_articles.abstract: BASICS are the Tao of fashion. Just when you think there's no further anyone can delve into their meaning -- no greater distance their versatility can be stretched -- someone finds a new way to mine their seemingly bottomless well of import. It isn't just jean ads, where wearers wax poetic about the inner life of a swatch of denim, or that chameleon-like Gap T-shirt (gee, anyone can wear it -- and they can wear it with anything!).    Take the pensive "Chic Simple Clothes" -- published last month by Knopf ($25) -- the rag-sploitation tome of its time. Its co-editors, Kim Johnson Gross and Jeff Stone, explain the book as an attempt to set out what quintessential style is today.

nytimes_articles.headline: Current Crop of College Graduates Finds Job Market Painfully Tight
nytimes_articles.abstract: As the nation's 1.3 million college seniors graduate this year, they face what economists and demographers call one of the harshest job climates in a quarter-century. The recession's lingering effects are chilling new job creation, while corporate cutbacks are altering the type of jobs available.   "Clearly, the recession has been tough," said Richard J. Murnane, a Harvard economist who has studied the job market. "Companies are using overtime instead of hiring, and line workers are increasingly college graduates."

nytimes_articles.headline: Editorial Notebook; New Age Filibusters
nytimes_articles.abstract: Poor James Madison seems to be bearing much of the blame these days for President Clinton's faltering start. One writer, Mickey Kaus in The New Republic, says that Madison's inspired handiwork -- the Constitution's checks and balances -- created a "gridlock machine." But it wasn't Madison who put the wrench in the machine. He didn't invent Senate Rule XXII. That's the rule permitting unlimited debate, and as presently construed, the measure makes it all too easy for a Senate minority to paralyze action, as Republicans did with Mr. Clinton's stimulus package.    There was a time, however, when senators who wished to block something really had to sweat. Today's filibusters are a paltry knockoff of the real thing.

nytimes_articles.headline:
ON THE JOB WITH PAUL BELLO;
'The Bug Doctor' Views the Seamy Side
nytimes_articles.abstract:
LITTLE makes Paul Bello more excited than a house with a really bad odor. Where lesser mortals run out in disgust with noses pinched shut, he rushes in to find the source. 

Mr. Bello, 38, is director of entomology and chief troubleshooter for the Arrow Exterminating Company, one of the largest companies of its kind in the New York metropolitan area. "I only get called in on the tough jobs," he said, "when a guy has been to a place a few times and there is still a problem."

nytimes_articles.headline: The Beach Is for Bikers
nytimes_articles.abstract: A seaside bicycle ride beneath the stars: a remarkably wholesome concept in a city famed for its sex appeal. Who could have imagined six months ago that three bikers would unwittingly launch a phenomenon of city spirit?   Back in December, it all seemed so simple. Marina Beserra, Roberto Braga and Sergio Guimaraes invited a few friends to take a nighttime bike ride along the beach. The next week, those friends asked a few more friends, and now their number is in the thousands. The Tuesday-night traffic is a municipal concern, and a giddy euphoria is in the air as Rio de Janeiro's besieged middle class claims back the night.

nytimes_articles.headline: POSTINGS: East 59th Reincarnation; Tenement To Town House
nytimes_articles.abstract: Take a walk along 59th Street, east of First Avenue, check out the neo-Colonial town house at No. 440, and you might think the building belongs in a historic district. Well, the nearest such district is blocks away, and the building's facade dates from 1993.   The building is the new home of Zoheir and Azita Aghravi and their three children. Looking for a larger apartment, and contemplating a resettlement in the suburbs, Mrs. Aghravi, a broker with Eastern Consolidated Properties, found a listing for a late-19th-century tenement building.

nytimes_articles.headline: Alexandra D. Alger, Daniel C. Chung
nytimes_articles.abstract: Alexandra Dewey Alger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Alger 3d of New York, was married there yesterday to Daniel Cayley Chung, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kai Lai Chung of Stanford, Calif. The Rev. Charles A. Amstein performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.   Ms. Alger, 31, is keeping her name. She is an associate editor at Venture Capital Journal, a magazine in New York. She graduated from Yale University and received a master's degree in journalism from Northwestern University. Her father heads Fred Alger Management Inc., an investment advisory company in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Q and A
nytimes_articles.abstract: Vikings in Newfoundland   Q. Are there any organized tours of Newfoundland that would include a visit to the Viking settlement at L'Anse aux Meadows? -- Gail Morin, Peru, N.Y.

nytimes_articles.headline: RESULTS PLUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: COLLEGE BASEBALL Texas, the Hard Way Brooks Kieschnick of Texas just did finish the job he started last night in the College World Series at Omaha. Suffering through an off night, the all-American pitcher allowed 12 hits and 5 runs and threw 172 pitches before the Longhorns edged Oklahoma State, 6-5, in a first-round game. Kieschnick (16-3), a first-round draft pick of the Chicago Cubs, gave up singles to Sean Hugo and Peter Prodanov in the ninth before making Thad Chaddrick his 11th strikeout victim to end the game. In an afternoon game, Darren Dreifort, Wichita State's relief ace, hit the game-winning home run in the 11th inning and then got the save as Wichita State defeated Arizona State, 4-3. Dreifort was within a strike of collecting his fifth save of the season in the ninth when A.S.U.'s Sean Tyler hit a homer to tie the score at 3-3. But Dreifort (11-1), a second-round choice of the Dodgers in the draft, hit his 21st homer to lead off the 11th and then survived a two-on rally in the bottom of the inning. Dreifort was chosen second by the Dodgers in the major league draft. (AP) TENNIS Navratilova Is Winner Top-seeded Martina Navratilova took advantage of the service errors and inexperience of Dutch teen-ager Kristie Boogert yesterday to post a 6-3, 6-3 victory at the Beckenham grass-court event in England. Navratilova then made a plea to Wimbledon's seeding committee to put her in the half of the draw that doesn't contain defending champion Steffi Graf. "I think I should be seeded joint No. 2 with Arantxa Sanchez Vicario behind Steffi," said the nine-time Wimbledon champion. Navratilova does not want to be seeded third and face the possibility of meeting Graf in the Wimbledon semifinals. The fifth-seeded Boogert, 19 years old, broke Navratilova's serve early in the second set but then was broken three times by the 36-year-old left-hander. In the men's semifinals of the exhibition tournament, second-seeded David Wheaton defeated fellow American Ken Flach, 6-7 (7-9), 6-3, 6-2. Wheaton, a Wimbledon semifinalist in 1991, will face Chris Bailey of Britain in today's final. Bailey also needed three sets to defeat 13th-seeded Grant Stafford of South Africa, 6-3, 6-7 (7-9), 6-3. (AP) TRACK AND FIELD Near-Miss for Bubka Sergei Bubka cleared 19 feet 2 1/4 inches, then barely missed a world pole vault record of 20-1 3/4 last night at the Prefontaine Classic in Eugene, Ore. The Ukrainian, who has set world records 34 times, got off to a rocky start by missing at 18-8 1/4. But he sailed easily over the bar on his second try at that height and on his first attempt at 19-2 1/4 before asking that the bar be set just above his world-record mark of 20-1 1/4. Last week, Bubka cleared 19-8 1/4 at the Bruce Jenner Classic last week for the highest vault ever on United States soil, but he did not attempt a world record then, waiting instead for the Prefontaine meet.   Both the Prefontaine meet and Bubka are sponsored by Nike. Bubka missed badly on his first world-record try but nearly cleared it on his second, knocking the bar off with his torso on the way down. His third attempt was even closer. He made it all the way over the bar but brushed it with his arms. The bar stayed in place for an instant, then fell. Bubka tied the meet and Hayward Field record set by Kory Tarpenning in 1988. Tarpenning was second yesterday at 18-8 1/4. (AP) Hometown Heroes: Luann Williams, former Clara Barton High School of Brooklyn star now at Odessa (Tex.) Junior College, took both women's sprints yesterday in the Coors/Metropolitan Athletics Congress outdoor track and field championships at St. John's. Williams, the national junior college champion in the 100 and 200 meters, won the 100 in 12 seconds and the 200 in 24.43 seconds yesterday, running for the Caribbean Connection Track Club. She almost lost the 100 when her starting blocks slipped, and she got off poorly. However, Williams made up ground quickly and caught Marissa Maggio of Anderson International at the tape as both were clocked in the same time. Charlene Neptune, Williams's teammate at Clara Barton, Odessa and the Caribbean Connection, finished first in the 1,500 meters in 4 minutes 32.47 seconds. She was second in the 800 meters at 2:10.34 behind Adina Valdez of the Westchester Track Club, who won in 2:06.52. In men's events, Ric Liddie of the Pioneer Club, former Andrew Jackson runner, upset Larry Gardner of Nike Atlantic in the 400 meters with a time of 47.77 seconds.  GOLF  Baker's Lead Is Cut Peter Baker, after shooting an even-par 72, had his three-stroke lead trimmed to one yesterday in the Dunhill British Masters in Woburn, England. Baker, a 25-year-old Briton who vaulted into the lead with a course record-tying 64 on Friday, managed a lone birdie on his third trip over the 6,940-yard Duke's course and was at 13-under 203. That left him just one shot ahead of countryman Carl Mason, Ronan Rafferty of Northern Ireland and Joakim Haeggman of Sweden. Mason and Haeggman shot 69's, and Rafferty, who birdied the last two holes, had a 70 and was at 204. Sandy Lyle, a former Masters titleholder at Augusta, followed his second-round 65 with a 70 and was another stroke off the pace at 205. Bernhard Langer, winner of this year's Masters at Augusta, fell five shots off the lead with a 71. (AP) Title for Florida: Florida won the team championship and Arizona State's Todd Demsey won the individual title at the N.C.A.A. men's tournament in Lexington, Ky., when Georgia Tech's David Duval couldn't par the final hole. Florida, which relinquished the lead to Georgia Tech after the third round and trailed by three strokes heading into the final 18 holes, shot a five-under-par 283 to finish at seven-under 1,145 on the par-72 Champions course. Georgia Tech was one stroke back while North Carolina finished third in the 15-team tournament with a five-under 1,147. Demsey, who had three birdies yesterday in recording a three-under 69, finished with a 10-under 278, while Duval's 70 put him a stroke back in second. The Gators, who also won the tournament in 1968 and 1973, clinched the title when Chris Couch sank a four-foot putt for par on No. 18. The Gators also won the tournament in 1968 and 1973. (AP) SOCCER Bundesliga Decided Bernd Hobsch scored two second-half goals and Werder Bremen shut out VfB Stuttgart, 3-0, yesterday in Berlin to capture the Bundesliga title. Bremen entered the game with the same 18-10-5 record as Bayern Munich, but Munich saw its hopes for a record 13th crown end in a 3-3 draw against Schalke. Bremen, the champion in 1965 and 1988, broke a 0-0 tie when Hobsch fired his first goal in the 46th minute. Thomas Wolter scored four minutes later to make the score 2-0, and Hobsch scored again in the 74th minute. Munich had been in first place since opening day before Bremen took over first last Saturday. Bayer Leverkusen secured a UEFA Cup berth for next season with its 4-0 victory over Monchengladbach. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: UP AND COMING: Valeria Golino; She Made Her Name Popping an Olive
nytimes_articles.abstract: Valeria Golino was 55 minutes late for lunch, but who's counting? That's the thing about these charmingly accented Italian actresses. They can be an hour late, and you're just glad they came at all.   "I'm so sorry," Ms. Golino said, sweeping into an Upper East Side bistro in a green pin-striped suit. Her entrance was not quiet.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dispute Grows as Tournament Nears
nytimes_articles.abstract:
AS a steady stream of Range Rovers, BMW's and Mercedes-Benzes cruised by the entrance to the Westchester Country Club here on a recent spring afternoon, a dozen striking workers lounged patiently on the side of the road, just as they had almost every day for nine months. The strikers -- 75 bartenders, waiters, cooks and dishwashers who walked off the job on Aug. 12 -- attracted hardly a passing glance as they chatted among themselves, occasionally exchanging a few cardboard placards emblazoned with the name of their union, Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union, Local 100, A.F.L.-C.I.O.

Tomorrow, however, barring an 11th-hour settlement, the small and quiet group of pickets will grow exponentially as the strikers call in union reinforcements from throughout the New York City area to carry out a planned threat to disrupt the opening of the weeklong Buick Classic Golf Tournament, a nationally televised sports event that last year raised nearly $1.5 million for 14 Westchester hospitals and several hundred thousand dollars for the Westchester Country Club, one of the most prestigious clubs in the country with one of the finest championship golf courses. Among those who are expected to play are Fred Couples, Ben Crenshaw and Tom Kite.
Dormitory Evictions

 In a victory for the union, the National Labor Relations Board last week declined to support a request by one of the Buick Classic's organizers, United Hospital of Port Chester, to designate one of the four entrances off-limits to the strikers, meaning that all who attend or participate in the Buick Classic must cross a picket line. According to organizers of the event, the tournament last year attracted 100,000 spectators to the Westchester Country Club during the course of the week.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Orlando,' Like Its Hero(ine), Is One for the Ages
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Do not fade, do not wither, do not grow old," the aged Queen Elizabeth I tells the young nobleman Orlando, making this fantastic request the condition on which she gives him a magnificent estate. So the writer and director Sally Potter sets her androgynous hero off through 400 years of history and sexual politics, barely pausing to change Orlando from man to woman along the way.    As a 17th-century man, a lovelorn Orlando condemns "the treachery of women"; in the 18th century he is so appalled by the macho code of war that he goes to sleep as one sex and wakes up another; and as a 19th-century woman, Orlando learns that she will lose the estate unless she has a son. Like the 1928 Virginia Woolf novel on which it is based, the screen version of "Orlando" is a delicious fantasy rooted in a rigorous sense of social history.

nytimes_articles.headline:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Beverly, Mass.;
Home Building Pace Increases
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THIS high-income oceanside town of 38,000 people about 30 miles north of Boston recently granted approvals for 112 one-family homes. In 1992, it issued about 15 approvals.

"This is the largest batch of approvals since we did about 75 approvals a year from 1984 through 1989," said Tina Cassidy, the Town Planning Director.

nytimes_articles.headline: Differing Views on Human Rights Threaten Forum
nytimes_articles.abstract: Deep divisions between developing and industrialized nations threaten the success of a conference this month on strengthening human rights. At issue is a contention by many third-world nations that Western standards of justice and fairness do not necessarily apply to other cultures.   Those countries are also seeking assurances that the West will not use their records on human rights to withhold aid or other economic benefits that the countries say would violate their right to development.

nytimes_articles.headline: Teaching Children How to Make Friends
nytimes_articles.abstract:
HE is a bright but awkward and immature 11-year-old fifth grader in a suburban Bergen County community. He has a speech problem, and the other children don't like him.

Nobody will eat lunch with him so he sits alone in the cafeteria. He is never picked to be on a team at recess. His classmates call him names like "weirdo" and "retard."

nytimes_articles.headline:
In the Region: Long Island;
Living, and Working, in the Hamptons
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE new four-bedroom house that Jim and Candice Ceravolo bought in April in Water Mill is not their vacation home but their year-round residence. 

Mr. Ceravolo, a commercial artist, specializes in large oil-on-canvas portraits and his clients include many stage celebrities. His wife is a graphics designer.

nytimes_articles.headline: Chinese Jade, Long Entombed, Comes To Vivid Life
nytimes_articles.abstract: Copper-colored jade? pink, brown, black and gray jade?    Jade in the usual colors of milky white or spinach green is virtually absent from the exhibition "Chinese Archaic Jades and Bronzes," at the Manhattan gallery of J. J. Lally and Company, through June. And the works on display are so minimal in decoration and form that they seem carved of a different material than the elaborately chiseled jades of the Ming dynasty and beyond.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ecological Concern Inspires Architects
nytimes_articles.abstract: YOU, too, can have the house of your dreams. Make it look like Grandma's, if that is your inclination, and show that you care about the earth and want to protect your health all at the same time.   Call it eco-design, sustainability, greening, environmental consciousness or any number of appelations, the concerns are the same and could not be more elementary to human need and well-being. It simply adds up to fresh air, climate control and safety -- yours and the planet's.

nytimes_articles.headline: America's Art Treasures Go to Schools on Video
nytimes_articles.abstract: Schools as diverse as one in a detention center in Miami for children awaiting court action and another in a poor Brooklyn neighborhood were among 700 chosen by the National Gallery of Art to receive free copies of a laser video disk containing the gallery's entire collection of American painting and sculpture.   Ruth R. Perlin, the head of the gallery's education resources department, said that the schools were selected on the basis of proposals they made.

nytimes_articles.headline: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
nytimes_articles.abstract: Holstein on Wheels   SITTING at a traffic light in a car that looks like a cow, one learns an important fact about New York drivers. Nothing, not even pink udders on a Honda Prelude, will distract them. Until the light turns green, the eyes stay straight ahead. Which means that quite a few Long Island drivers missed quite a sight on Main Street in Smithtown.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sapristi! Is This Our Tintin?
nytimes_articles.abstract: TINTIN IN THE NEW WORLD A Romance. By Frederic Tuten. 239 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Jersey Q & A: Roy Gillian; Lessons in Running an Amusement Park
nytimes_articles.abstract: Roy Gillian followed his father into the amusement park business, and he has, in turn, brought his three sons, Jim, Steve and Jay, into the operation of Gillian's Wonderland Pier. It is something of a landmark in this seaside resort, which was founded as a summer colony for vacationing Methodists at the turn of the century.   And Mr. Gillian himself, at 63 years of age, has achieved considerable stature -- in Ocean City, where he was once the Mayor; in Trenton, where he has often appeared before the Legislature as a member and former president of the 200-member New Jersey Amusement Association, and in the councils of the International Association of Amusement Parks and Attractions, an organization with more than 3,000 members in 54 countries, which he now serves as president.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pomp And Protest
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IF the protest goes as planned, hundreds of students at Harvard University will march to their graduation ceremony on Thursday wearing a political statement.

Their target: the military, as personified by the commencement speaker, Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tammy Koehler, George Dorfman
nytimes_articles.abstract: Tammy Fay Koehler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dale Koehler of Canton, Ohio, was married yesterday to George J. Dorfman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Dorfman of Gloversville, N.Y. Arthur Marchesi, a town justice in Freeville, N.Y., officiated at the Rose Inn in Lansing, N.Y.   Mrs. Dorfman, 26, is the assistant director of the Wellness Program, an exercise and nutrition program for the faculty and students at Cornell University. She graduated from the University of Toledo, from which she received a master's degree in education.

nytimes_articles.headline: Danielle Sproul, Kevin Sullivan
nytimes_articles.abstract: Danielle A. Sproul, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald A. Sproul 4th of Evanston, Ill., was married yesterday to Kevin M. Sullivan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael P. Sullivan of Charlotte, N.C. The Rev. Richard Leonard performed the Unitarian ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York.   Mrs. Sullivan, 31, is a vice president and management supervisor at Lowe & Partners, an advertising agency in New York. She graduated from the University of Illinois and received an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pamela S. Hise, Justin Sullivan
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mr. and Mrs. Phillip W. Hise of Rochester have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela S. Hise, and Justin J. Sullivan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Sullivan of New York. A November wedding is planned.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gusto, Imported From Canada
nytimes_articles.abstract: The choreographer who can make performers look especially good is beloved by dancers and audiences alike. Witness the huge success Les Grands Ballets Canadiens has recently enjoyed in New York with two box-office hits in just that category -- James Kudelka's "Desir" and Nacho Duato's "Na Floresta."   Both were choreographed to fit a company that has never been easy to define. What is one to make of a troupe that achieved international pop celebrity in the early 1970's with "Tommy," the first ballet version of the rock opera by the Who, and also continued to perform Balanchine ballets and "Swan Lake"?  This is not your customary eclecticism: The range is exceptionally wide, and the frequent turnover of directors in the Grands Ballets has reflected a search for identity.

nytimes_articles.headline: Restaurateur on a Frogmobile
nytimes_articles.abstract: There's a new, youthful presence at La Grenouille, and it's not a result of plastic surgery.   In January, the 30-year-old French restaurant on East 52d Street lost its longtime manager, Charles Masson, 38, who was responsible for La Grenouille's inspired flower arrangements, among other things. Mr. Masson, whose father founded the restaurant, now works with Robert Isabell, the floral designer.

nytimes_articles.headline: EX-MIAMI OFFICER WANTS JOB BACK
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the dismay of local civil rights groups, a Hispanic policeman convicted here of killing two young black men, but then acquitted on the same charges last week in a second trial in Orlando, is seeking to return to active duty.   In his only interview since his acquittal, the officer, William Lozano, told a Spanish-language television station here that he would request reinstatement to active duty, which, if successful, would enable him to recover lost wages. The 33-year-old police officer, born in Colombia, was relieved of duty without pay after being convicted of manslaughter in Miami in 1989, but the verdict was overturned in 1991 when a panel of judges ruled that jurors may have feared an outbreak of racial violence if they acquitted Mr. Lozano. He was acquitted by a jury in Orlando on May 28 after a three-week trial.

nytimes_articles.headline: Colleagues Remember Slain Newark Detective as Fearless
nytimes_articles.abstract: Each day that he went out on his undercover narcotics investigations, Detective John Sczyrek carried a cloth laundry bag, all tie-dyed red, blue and purple, on his shoulder. To colleagues, it was his trademark. To Detective Sczyrek, it was his "trick bag," a depository of disguises he drew on to blend into the underworld of drug trafficking and fool his targets.   On Thursday morning he left the bag at his locker at the Newark Police Department's narcotics squad. His assignment for the day was to take him worlds away from the dangerous streets and his regular chore of outwitting drug dealers. His day's task was on the 11th floor of the Essex County Court Building, testifying at the trial of two men he arrested last August on drug and weapons charges after they sold him $20 worth of narcotics in a Newark apartment.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Murder at Marriott' To Benefit Lung Group
nytimes_articles.abstract:
COUNTESS Alona Jemsley is throwing a masquerade ball, and a lot of interesting characters are invited. 

Among those expected to attend is Dr. Renuzit who, according to pre-party publicity, attends all society galas because "he has lifted every face that can afford him." And Ambassador and Mrs. Claire Hissinger -- he hasn't been an ambassador for years, but "continues to spout international pearls of wisdom." And Shoo-Shoo Scarpati, who has a habit of traveling with a shoehorn and asking every woman he meets what her shoe size is.

nytimes_articles.headline: Where the Buffalo Roam
nytimes_articles.abstract:
AFTER getting her first faceful of buffalo breath, my young daughter wondered if buffalo had surrounded covered wagons crossing the Great Plains, as the beggarly beasts had done to our compact car at the Olympic Game Farm, a wildlife park in Sequim, Wash. It was a question to ponder later at a gas station on Highway 101 as I took a squeegee to our car windows, washing away the evidence of huge, shaggy heads dragging their wet lips and beards across our windshield, trying to charm us into tossing them a few pieces of stale bread.

While I wrestled with the squeegee, traffic going either way on the highway kept up a dull roar. Not a lot of people seemed to be stopping in Sequim (pronounced skwim), my favorite Olympic Peninsula town, not even to pause to admire the large herd of wild elk grazing a few yards from the city limits sign.

nytimes_articles.headline: Son of Best Seller Stalks the Moors
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE book business, which hardly used to be a business at all, has in the last 10 years begun to search for The Next Big Thing with a zeal once found only in the movie business. And what is The Next Big Thing in the book biz? Oh honey-chickie-baby, have I got an answer for you. Ready? O.K.: Sequel rights. Did you get it? Good.

Warner Books was the company that really got in on the ground floor this time, but don't hate 'em for it; if you're willing to risk the cash cow, you deserve to drink the cream, right? Oh honey-chickie-baby you are so totally correct it hurts.

nytimes_articles.headline: Grannies With Dash
nytimes_articles.abstract: The revived one-piece flower-print granny dress has zoomed to the top of the spring-summer fashion charts. For a generation weaned on jeans and sportswear, wearing dresses is a new experience. Mothers and grandmothers might wince at how their common housedress prints are now being worn: with Doc Martens, and sweaters tied around the waist, or with the button fronts left undone when worn over leggings or jeans. The look is a movement by younger women to create their own signature look, while deconstructing designer concepts of ladylike dressing.

nytimes_articles.headline: Seniors Work Plan Spreads in Schools
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WHEN colleagues talk about Victor Leviatin, 54, co-founder of Westchester Individualized Senior Experience, they tend to come up with words like "prophet," "man with a mission" and "inspiring human being."

WISE, the acronym for the nonprofit foundation, is an outgrowth of the Woodlands Individualized Senior Experience at the Greenburgh high school. It is a transitional program that gives graduating seniors an experience of working independently in the adult world under the guidance of a mentor.

nytimes_articles.headline: At AIDS Talks, Science Confronts Daunting Maze
nytimes_articles.abstract: After more than a decade of intensive research, scientists boast that they have learned more faster about H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, than about any other microbe.   Yet to H.I.V.-infected patients and the public, the scientists' wealth of knowledge contrasts sharply with the poverty of clinical benefits it has yielded. The most impressive gains in fighting AIDS have been made in treating the opportunistic infections that develop as the immune system collapses.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Less-Than-Intrepid Urban Sleuth Takes First Steps Into the Suburbs
nytimes_articles.abstract:
NINA FISCHMAN is not the sharpest detective around, nor is she the most adventurous. She doesn't make much money as a lawyer for the New York City Housing Authority, and her social life includes very few encounters with men who might be marriage material. In fact, Nina doesn't even want to play detective and is often intimidated by suspects. 

Yet she always manages to capture the crooks, and the creator of Nina Fischman, Marissa Piesman, appears poised to capture a wider audience for her witty urban-flavored mysteries.

nytimes_articles.headline: Graf Battles Back to Win French Final
nytimes_articles.abstract: Steffi Graf, tense in the beginning but remorseless by the conclusion of her three-set final with Mary Joe Fernandez this simmering afternoon, captured her first French Open title since 1988, and the 12th Grand Slam tournament of her career. She did it with a 4-6, 6-2, 6-4 comeback effort that underlined her recent recovery of the world's No. 1 ranking.   "I had a few close matches here in the last few years," said Graf, who was runner-up to three-time champion Monica Seles in 1990 and 1992, "and I was always the one who had to play against the better player at the end, so I was thankful that it was the other way around today."

nytimes_articles.headline: The Pro Arena Isn't for Training
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Sports Editor:   Although William C. Rhoden is probably well-intentioned in trying to correct a perceived wrong by observing a "striking contrast between the black faces on the court and the mostly white faces in the media area," he continues to tow the sinking line of liberals who still do not get it.

nytimes_articles.headline: For New Parents, a Golden Opportunity
nytimes_articles.abstract: "WE see people come in all the time with children on their laps. They're there to have us check their brakes, but they come in and the children are lying across the seat, not strapped in at all. They didn't even think about the child, but they're worried about their brakes!"   That is Sheila Schube talking in Maspeth, Queens, and she is the regional chairman of a helpful national program that has just come to New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Schube owns a Midas muffler shop in Maspeth, and like others who own the 1,800 Midas shops around the country, she is trying to save the children.

nytimes_articles.headline:
DANCE;
. . . Including 3-Part Chronicle of the West
nytimes_articles.abstract:
SUNBONNETS shield faces from a relentless Western sun as a band of pioneers struggles slowly across a prairie in a Conestoga wagon. A turbulent river rises to engulf them, and a craggy mountain range looms up to defy the courageous group of men and women whose dramatic story forms the choreographed material of "Ghosts of an Old Ceremony." 

"Ghosts" is the first section of "Western Women," a three-act dance chronicle by Brenda Way that will be performed by ODC/San Francisco on Thursday, Friday and Saturday at 8 P.M. at the New Theater of Rutgers in New Brunwick as part of the Rutgers Summerfest. The second section, "Falling in Place," deals with women's struggles to come of age in American society; the third, "Dirt," propels the chronicle into the urban maelstrom of the 1960's.

nytimes_articles.headline: A New Generation on Old Broadway
nytimes_articles.abstract: "All About Eve," the smartest movie ever made about Broadway, begins and ends with a glamorous awards ceremony at which decorous theater people speak fondly of their art and one another while accepting trophies and preening for the cameras. During the two hours of flashback that come in between, the characters, including a dyspeptic drama critic, are revealed as a bunch of back-stabbing schemers at worst and childlike dreamers at best. When the Broadway of "All About Eve" gives birth to a prize-winning performance or play, it does so despite its own denizens' mean-spiritedness and whimsical artistic instincts.   Much about the street has changed beyond recognition since 1950, the year Joseph L. Mankiewicz's masterpiece was sent forth by Hollywood. Not even Addison DeWitt, the critic in "All About Eve," could have foreseen a season like that of 1992-93 in which two hits (one of them starring an extant sensation of the 1950's, Chita Rivera) offer uncloseted gay protagonists and onstage scenes of simulated defecation. Nor could anyone have predicted 40 years ago that Broadway's rate of production would slow to a trickle by the 1990's -- from 60 productions as late as the 1980-81 season to only 32 this season -- or that most important new American dramas would only play Broadway as if it were another stop on the road or even bypass Broadway entirely.

nytimes_articles.headline: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: STUDIO OPEN HOUSE   The studio of William Chadwick, a member of Old Lyme's colony of 20th-century American Impressionist painters, will open today for public viewing, surrounded by gardens on the grounds of the Florence Griswold Museum.   The studio was donated to the museum by the artist's daughter-in-law, Elizabeth Chadwick O'Connell, and moved from its original site off Shore Road to the museum's property. It has been restored to its appearance when Mr. Chadwick painted there from 1920 to 1962. Many of the original furnishings and accessories, and the artist's painting equipment were preserved and have been installed.

nytimes_articles.headline: Shouting Obscures Arts Agency's Good Work; Close the Endowment
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   If President Clinton appoints a chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts who supports the "decency standard" passed by Congress, he or she will be opposed by the arts establishment. But if Mr. Clinton nominates someone who wants the Government to subsidize art that violates the mores of the average citizen, he will offend many voters.    "Waiting for the Appointment: Who Will Be the Arts Chief?" The Week in Review, May 23, advises Mr. Clinton to go along with such subsidies because "the arts, like health and education, are a social good, and even if sometimes painful (insofar as they appear to be obscene to the public), they deserve to be supported by the Federal Government."

nytimes_articles.headline: So Weak, So Powerfull
nytimes_articles.abstract: HERE is how Kate Moss looks in the picture: very young and very dead. Skin waxen, eyes unfocused, she's an amalgam of Laura Palmer in "Twin Peaks" and the young woman's corpse found abandoned amid the scrub oaks and yucca trees in the movie "River's Edge."    The picture is one of eight such images in this month's British Vogue, all shot by Corinne Day, a former model who is Ms. Moss's friend. Ms. Moss is pictured in her sparsely furnished apartment clad variously in T-shirts and underpants with the label showing, and panty hose that don't fit. She gazes into space; she looks out a window, she waits moodily -- a passive little match girl for the 1990's enfolded in a pale mauve comforter, wearing gray socks and a navy La Perla bra available at Nightingales for $:87.

nytimes_articles.headline: If You're Thinking of Living in: New Canaan
nytimes_articles.abstract: IN much of the 19th century, New Canaan was a community of farmers, blacksmiths, carpenters, weavers and coopers. One day in 1830 the owner of Hoyt's General Store on Main Street had an attack of temperance and smashed his stock of liquor on the roadway. An astonished citizenry watched as all that good rum, gin and bourbon sank into the dust.   "The general store was where you bought liquor," said Mary Louise King, historian of what is now part of Connecticut's Gold Coast. "The town would vote to be wet or dry, back and forth every few years. We used to have more liquor stores than groceries, and until 1915 we had more Democrats than Republicans."

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Nunsense II' Stays Close to the Original
nytimes_articles.abstract: SEQUELS to films like "Rocky" or "Alien" are commonplace, and on occasion the subsequent I's, II's and III's are as good, even sometimes better, as the original.   In theater, however, the sequel syndrome has never caught on. It is difficult to reassemble a creative team, and the costs involved in producing a new version of an old story are as prohibitive as staging an original. Plus the specter of major flop sequels like "Annie II" and "Bring Back Birdie" hovers over the offices of wary angels.

nytimes_articles.headline: SIHANOUK WORKING ON NEW COALITION
nytimes_articles.abstract: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, deepening a royal family feud that has threatened to undermine his efforts to create a coalition government, said today that he would try again to forge a coalition despite the objections of his 49-year-old son, the leader of the party that won the election.   In a speech carried on state-run television and radio, addressed in Prince Sihanouk's usual fashion to "my children and grandchildren," he said he had been forced to abandon his first attempt at creating a government because of protests from the son, Prince Norodom Ranariddh.

nytimes_articles.headline: In a One-Man Show, Joel Grey Is a Crowd
nytimes_articles.abstract: If Joel Grey rolls up his pants to the knees, opens his baby blues to their full circumference and puts a little red-and-white schoolboy's cap on his head, he can, at the age of 61, pass for 8. By puffing up his cheeks, extending his arms out from his sides and lowering his body to a seated position -- although there is no chair nearby for him to sit on -- he is able to transform himself rather convincingly into a frog. And when he lets his wrists melt, allows his hips to expand in a circular swivel and draws his mouth into the shape of a rosebud, he could be any floozy in the lobby of a third-rate hotel looking for a good time.   Mr. Grey can also sing and dance, by the way.

nytimes_articles.headline:
DINING OUT;
Shades of California Cuisine in Airmont
nytimes_articles.abstract:
JUDGING by the number of diners awaiting tables, this sweet little Rockland County restaurant has already been discovered, and not only by a local clientele. As the Citrus Grille is only four or five miles from the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway (Route 87), motorists plying the highway at mealtime have also found Citrus Grille a rewarding stop, but reservations are a must. 

The place is bright and informal. Anything goes, from suit and tie to shirt sleeves. Lime-green walls that set off the splashes of bloom on the comfortable upholstered chairs, arrangements of fruit and dried flowers and a bit of stained glass make the major decorating statements. A harlequin mirror, a leftover from the previous occupant, is an off note. While comfortable, Citrus Grille puts most of its effort into the food rather than the decor.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bicyclists Pedal On, Despite Urban Perils
nytimes_articles.abstract: Although Devon Ruiz hung up his saddlebag a few years ago when he stopped being a bicycle messenger, he said the scrappy lessons he learned criscrossing avenues abuzz with the blurred cavalcade of traffic and pedestrians remain with him. But there comes a point, in his mind at least, where luck overtakes road smarts.   "You can't be too cautious," he said Friday afternoon, pausing from his lazy glide along West 90th Street in Manhattan. "You just have to ride and hope for the best." 2 Cyclists Dead and 1 Injured    The city's cyclists were hard pressed for hope last week. Beyond the usual streetside hazards of chaotic traffic, foul-mouthed motorists and determined bike thieves, there came the dispiriting news: drivers without proper licenses struck two Manhattan men, killing one, while a drama teacher out for a sun-dappled spin in Brooklyn's Prospect Park was shot and killed during a bicycle theft gone awry. The police arrested four teen-agers in the shooting.

nytimes_articles.headline: Making Life a Bit Better for Someone Else
nytimes_articles.abstract:
TWENTY FIVE years ago, in the days following the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., a small group of people from St. Luke's Parish in Darien gathered to talk about ways they could get out into the surrounding community and do some good. "The country was in the midst of a period of considerable anguish," Janet Brown said, "and we felt there had to be something we could do to help makes things even a little better." 

Because members of the parish lived in an affluent community, they wanted to share some of what they had with people who had little and needed a lot. The group decided to try to meet three needs: food, clothing and furniture. They encouraged friends to clean out their closets, and they gathered bags of clothes. They visited people who were redecorating their homes and hauled away furniture that was no longer needed, delivering it to people in Stamford by way of an old station wagon. The group spread the word about a need for food and soon had a well-stocked pantry for families with emergency needs.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rabies Cases Spread to More Towns
nytimes_articles.abstract: ON May 26 Windsor Locks joined 102 other Connecticut towns in identifying their first case of rabies. Although 103 Connecticut towns have reported rabid animals in the last two years and the disease is spreading rapidly throughout the state, Dr. Maxine A. LeGeyt, a Vernon veterinarian and expert on rabies, said, "We're coping quite well. Other states are looking at Connecticut to see how to handle rabies."    Fairfield County is completely saturated with the disease, Litchfield County heavily infected. Other parts of the state west of the Connecticut River are experiencing an upsurge in cases with the spring population boom, according to Dr. LeGeyt. More than 1,300 cases of rabies have been identified in wild and domestic animals throughout Connecticut since 1991. "We have been expecting rabies here since 1986," said the director of the Connecticut Veterinary Medical Association, Harry Shook. The disease has been traveling through the Middle Atlantic region since 1977. Though thousands of exposures have been counted nationally, not one case of human rabies has been identified because the post-exposure treatment is so effective, Dr. LeGeyt said.  Ebbs and Flows    The virus ebbs and flows in a cycle that depends on how fast the wildlife re-populates. Cases will decline first in the areas first affected, like Fairfield County. A decline is expected in these areas in two to three years, said Dr. LeGeyt.

nytimes_articles.headline:
SUMMER VACATIONS;
A Dude Tries The Ranch Life In Colorado
nytimes_articles.abstract:
I'D never been on a horse, I wasn't big on adventure and I didn't have much curiosity about the great outdoors. So what exactly possessed me to suggest to my family an elemental vacation in the Wild West -- whitewater rafting for five days on the Green River in Utah, followed by a week at a dude ranch in central Colorado? It may have been that I was turning 40. Nor could I deny some stirrings as I watched Billy Crystal and his buddies sitting around a campfire with real-life cowboys in "City Slickers." And, more simply still, our whole family had had it with sedentary, surprise-free vacations by the beach. So off west we went.

My kids were in rapture almost from the moment we arrived at Lost Valley Ranch, late on a Sunday afternoon in August. For Deborah and me, it was the setting that first captured our hearts: a working ranch nine miles down a dirt road in the 23,000-acre Pike National Forest, in a sweeping valley surrounded on every side by majestic mountains. For Kate, 11, and Emily, 7, the horses were the instant source of excitement. After the wranglers put on a welcoming mini-rodeo, we all walked over to the stables. As the kids were being fitted to saddles, it dawned on them that they were about to be given horses of their own for the next week -- huge, sleek animals fully prepared to take them wherever they wanted to go. From that moment on, our children became utterly self-sufficient. They had the run of the ranch. They rode with their peers, and we spent time with them at meals, by the pool in the late afternoon and after their evening activities.

Beyer of Tewksbury, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Katherine Lesley Jones Beyer to Hilary Thomas Childs, a son of Margaret Burden Childs of Fairfield, Conn., and Daniel R. nytimes_articles.headline:
TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Mexico Sets Up Roadside Checks For Narcotics
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Tourists driving in Mexico this summer can expect to see more of the Mexican police than usual. Last month checkpoints were being set up on many of the country's major highways, in what the Mexican Attorney General's office said was an attempt to stem drug trafficking and crime on the roads. (The plan was being implemented well before the fatal shooting late last month of Juan Jesus Cardinal Posadas Ocampo and six other people at Guadalajara Airport. Officials said the shooting was a fight between rival groups of drug traffickers, and that the Cardinal was mistaken for one of them.)

The first highway checkpoints are being established in Mexico's northern and Pacific coast states, including Baja California Norte, Sonora and Chihuahua, and in southern states like Oaxaca and Chiapas. In the next three months, 19 checkpoints will be set up in 13 states, followed by additional ones throughout the rest of Mexico, according to a spokeswoman in the office of Mexico's Attorney General.

nytimes_articles.headline: Main Yeltsin Rival Bolts Constitution Conference
nytimes_articles.abstract: As a constitutional conference intended to chart Russia's political future opened today, the chairman of Russia's Parliament stormed out, accusing President Boris N. Yeltsin of pushing ahead with a new constitution that would move the country toward a dictatorship.   The departure of the chairman, Ruslan I. Khasbulatov, who was followed by about 50 other delegates, cast a pall over prospects for the smooth adoption of the country's first post-Communist constitution, an effort that Mr. Yelstin described as "a most important watershed in the life in the Russian state."

nytimes_articles.headline: Professional Women's Group Turns 10
nytimes_articles.abstract: WOMEN in such fields as public relations, advertising and design, marketing and journalism will celebrate the 10th anniversary of the Westchester chapter of Women in Communications on Wednesday at 6 P.M. with an awards dinner at the Stouffer Westchester Hotel in Harrison.   Judy Matson, director of the county's Office of Cultural Affairs and a founder of the Westchester chapter of the support network, will receive the Matrix Award, the group's highest honor. Denise C. Weizner, the chapter's outgoing president, said the award was made yearly on the basis of service to the community, professional excellence and service to the chapter. An Identity of Its Own    Women in Communications was founded in 1909 as Theta Sigma Phi at the University of Washington and now has more than 10,000 members -- both women and men -- in professional and student chapters nationwide and abroad. Although the organization was founded by journalists, the Westchester chapter, which is among the 10 largest chapters in the country, has taken on a distinct identity of its own.

nytimes_articles.headline: Montreal Surges, Falters, Endures

The Kings' defenseman was discussing how the Montreal Canadiens stormed the goal crease and scored to win the game, 4-3, on a goal by John LeClair and take a two-games-to-one lead in the Stanley Cup finals.   LeClair's first shot got by Kelly Hrudey, the Los Angeles goalie, but slithered wide of the post. McSorley and his teammates went for the rebound. So did LeClair and friends. Brian Bellows of Montreal set a pick at the post while Hrudey scrambled across the crease, unable to rise to his skates. McSorley collided with a teammate, Tony Grantao. nytimes_articles.headline: When Recipes Are Not Recipes, but Ideas
nytimes_articles.abstract: OVER the years, among the many major culinary trends, two polar-opposite positions have evolved in the recipe-writing business. One sort of food writer assumes that the cook wants and needs to be told what to do in a prescriptive fashion -- make it work, make it beautiful. But from the opposite camp come recipes aimed at some presumably smaller number of cooks who are confident enough and experienced enough to search out the cooking tutors who will simply show them the way and set them free.   Elizabeth David, the British food writer, was renowned for being a cookbook author in the latter camp (the American chef Anne Rosenzweig once said of David's writing: "Recipes were not recipes; they were ideas"). More recently, there have been many other strong examples of the approach. Among contemporary books, Shirley King's "Fish: The Basics" comes to mind for its willingness to give direction and then trust the cook to do something with it.

nytimes_articles.headline:
TRAVEL;
Arcadia: Last of the Head Trips
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE travel book, like the novel, is a literary genre apparently without rules. Fourteen lines are mandatory in a sonnet, and a tragedy must end with someone's death, but the travel book is free from precept or precedent: it needs only to describe a journey, which writing -- as the movement of language through time -- automatically does. Nevertheless, the best travel books owe a secret allegiance to one of the most ancient literary genres: they all turn out to be versions of pastoral.

Pastoral is the form that depicts the paradise we have lost, the rustic simplicity of a good life in a golden age. The pastoral ideal of the classical poets, from Theocritus to Sir Philip Sidney, was irretrievably distant in time. For the travel writer, the idyll is teasingly remote in space, but can be reached by consulting the airline schedules.

nytimes_articles.headline: IN THE NATURAL STATE
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IN the attic I could hear Linda rummaging through our camping gear, and I could sense her exasperation. It had been several years and one house move since we'd been on a road trip. Tents and sleeping bags burrow their way to the bottom of piles with less provocation than this.

Our dog, Moose, was standing in the door, edgy as a cat. He had seen these preparations before and knew that fate hung in the balance for him -- a summer of fun or weeks nursing his loss in the kennel. He had no way of knowing that it would not be the former, and I had no way of easing his burden.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'This Town Will Die Without Our School'

"It's the kind of town where you're born, you go to school, get married, raise a family and die," said Janet Glynos, a Kenilworth native.    Now, forces inside and outside the community have combined to endanger its way of life. Since 1970, the population has declined by almost 1,600 people. A new shopping center and supermarket are going up on one end of town, threatening the downtown businesses. And David Brearley Regional High School, which Charles Vitale, a former school board president, calls "the social and civic hub of the town," is scheduled to be closed at the end of the 1993 school year.

nytimes_articles.headline: Orff: Two Second Thoughts
nytimes_articles.abstract: If ever a composer could be said to have fallen out of favor, it is Carl Orff. His flamboyant scenic cantata "Carmina Burana" is occasionally performed on pops programs or by ballet companies. His educational ideas, usually adulterated by the Kodaly method or another pedagogical approach, are still applied in schools. But of the considerable breadth of his achievement, there is little representation.   So the budget reissue of the sole studio recording of Orff's quasi-opera "Antigonae" (Deutsche Grammophon 437 721-2; three CD's) is of particular interest. Now available by import and set for American release later this year, it can be profitably compared with a newly released historical album of the 1949 world premiere at the Salzburg Festival (Stradivarius STR 10060; two CD's).

nytimes_articles.headline: Bringing Dinos Back to Life

For close-ups, the film makers often used full-size robots by the model-maker Stan Winston. When the dinosaurs are in motion, however, viewers will probably be looking at computer animation.   The animation took place at Industrial Light and Magic, the California special-effects house. The company, which has also handled special effects for "The Abyss" and "Terminator 2: Judgment Day," used the dinosaur robots designed by Mr. Winston (such as the seven-foot velociraptors pictured here) as guides. The animation alone took 18 months. Meanwhile, other technicians blocked out the actions of the invisible dinosaurs on the movie set.

nytimes_articles.headline: Eastham, Cape Cod's Little Secret
nytimes_articles.abstract: HALFWAY between the elbow and knuckles of Cape Cod, Massachusetts' long arm flexing into the Atlantic, lies a little town that most vacationers hardly notice. "You can pass through the village centers of Eastham and North Eastham and never know you've been there," notes one guidebook. And it's almost true. Bisected by Route 6, Cape Cod's main artery, Eastham appears at first glance to have little of even passing interest, besides a glimpse of water and a vaguely hat-shaped visitor center. To most hurried visitors, "the gateway" to the National Seashore, as Eastham is known, remains a stop for gas on the way to the beach; for those who pause a moment longer on their way to Wellfleet or Provincetown, it's a straggle of efficiency cottages, a few motels and a handful of slightly faded roadside attractions. No blown glass, no band concerts, no yacht club.    But for those who linger, Eastham provides its own quiet blandishments. The sun rises over the ocean on one edge of town, and sets a few miles away over Cape Cod Bay. In between sunrise and sunset, you can swim across a couple of freshwater ponds, or brood by a salt marsh. A watery, drifting place, Eastham loses a bit of itself every year to the tides, shored up only by beach grass and scrub pine. Where the ground isn't spongy, it's sandy. Long ago, I decided that this tentative quality must be why Eastham has stayed so unassuming, blessedly free of choked harbors, of restaurants that treat lobster as haute cuisine, of golf courses larger than half an acre. Instead it's a mom-and-pop kind of town; the same family has always owned the general store, and a rented bicycle comes with a desultory chat about back roads, and a reminder to wear a helmet. When you spot someone wearing Spandex on the bike path, you know he's ridden in from somewhere else.
